A study of more than 25,000 blood samples detected no blood donors with HIV-2 infection. The CDC concluded that adding HIV-2 tests to routine blood donor screening wouldn't be worth the cost of more than $60 million a year.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysian Museum Hunts Up Skulls From Around the World
LaserPhoto KL2
DOC.TEXT: The National Museum says you may touch the artifacts in a coming exhibition, but it's not for the faint-at-heart. The display will include human skulls, deformed craniums and shrunken heads from around the world. Mexican cake in the shape of human skulls, headhunting weapons and Hollywood posters with macabre titles like ``Brain Eater,'' ``Headhunter,'' ``Scalp hunters,'' and ``Skulduggery'' are also among the items. The show, dubbd ``Heads and Skulls in Human Culture and History,'' took a year to prepare. Underwritten by a local company, it begins Jan. 16 and lasts for a year. Shahrum Bin Yub, the director-general of the government's Museums Division, says the aim of the show is to educate, inform and dispel superstition by showing headhunting as it was practiced in many parts of the world as late as the early part of this century. Shahrum says he made two world tours collecting artifacts from museums and universities for the exhibition. He said he brought back about 100 skulls. He has just returned from Mexico, where he attended the six-day Celebration of the Dead. He saw children eating little cakes shaped as skulls, so he brought some back for display. Shahrum says the exhibition will include skulls, weapons used in headhunting, costumes, and shields. He said that in some societies, headhunting was viewed as an initiation rite. A young man seeking to marry or pass into manhood had to bring back a head, usually of his enemy. Some of the skulls contain holes made with primitive tools. Shahrum explained that people in certain societies believed that headaches were caused by evil spirits, so holes were made in the skulls to free the spirits. The cure was no doubt more painful than the headache. An example comes from Africa in 1957. An expedition encountered a living example of the skull-boring practice known as trephination - a man from the Tibu tribe. He had two huge scars in his scalp and carried in his pocket two fragments of his own skull. Among the prize exhibits is the well-preserved skull of a Chinese, Jimmy Ah Sue, who was hanged in Australia in 1880. His skull, borrowed from an Australian museum, survived long after he was gone because a Russian scientist wanted to study his brain. During the exhibition, there will be a demonstration of phrenology, the analysis of character by studying the shape of the skull. The exhibition will also focus on how skulls are used in primitive art. Shahrum is preparing a 400-page booklet on the customs and practices of people who headhunted. For instance, headhunters in Assam in northeastern India believed that the head possessed potent magical powers and that the human soul resided there. Thus, possessing someone's head meant owning his soul and controlling his power. Shahrum is no stranger to the dark side of the archival life. His current Treasures from the Grave exhibition has attracted about 700,000 people, including many foreign tourists. A prize exhibit is an Egyptian mummy borrowed from a British museum.

DOC.HEAD: New York Daily News Loses Big Advertisers as Strike Persists
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News, its circulation devastated by a month-long strike, has lost one of its biggest advertisers, Macy's department store, just as the heavy holiday advertising season is getting under way. Macy's confirmed Friday it has dropped its advertising in the Daily News, and officials for striking unions said the A&S department store, another big advertiser, has done the same. The newspaper's two tabloid rivals, the New York Post and New York Newsday, have reported large advertising and circulation gains since the strike began Oct. 25. ``This is obviously all strike-related,'' Newsday spokeswoman Chiara Coletti said. Newsday's Friday paper had 192 advertising pages, 24 more than a year ago, according to the newspaper. The Post's Friday edition had 90 ad pages, 40 more than last year's, officials at the newspaper said. Friday's Daily News had 47 pages of advertising. The newspaper's spokeswoman, Lisa Robinson, refused to discuss the departure of advertisers. The Post and Newsday featured ads from Macy's and A&S. Neither store took out ads in Friday's Daily News. Liz Holland, a Macy's spokeswoman, said the store was no longer advertising in the Daily News. Jim White, director of operations for A&S, declined to say if his store had dropped the newspaper. A&S ads have not appeared in the Daily News since Tuesday. Nine unions are striking the newspaper over what they term unfair labor conditions. The Daily News has published every day since the strike began, but many vendors have refused to sell it. The Daily News had a daily circulation of 1.09 million before the strike. It has said it is now printing 600,000 papers a day and getting 400,000 to customers. New York Newsday officials said their paper's daily circulation has risen from about 150,000 before the strike to about 340,000. The paper's Long Island edition has a circulation of about 600,000. Post officials said their newspaper's circulation is up from about 500,000 before the strike to between 700,000 and 750,000.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Says Vatican Pressure Won't Get Him to Back Down on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic archbishop denied an honorary doctorate degree because he surveyed women on their reasons for seeking abortions says Vatican pressure won't keep him from speaking out. ``I can't imagine (being stopped) unless you take out my tongue,'' Archbishop Rembert Weakland said Friday. ``I must admit I may be too upbeat about it. Maybe that's not good'' Weakland said he respects the church's opposition to abortion but thinks church leaders should examine the reasons why Catholic women are willing to seek abortions anyway. Switzerland's University of Fribourg had planned to award Weakland an honorary doctorate this week, but canceled the ceremony after pressure from the Vatican's Congregation of Education. In the letter to Fribourg, Vatican officials accused Weakland of ``causing confusion among the faithful'' concerning abortion. Weakland held six hearings this year for women in the Milwaukee Archdiocese, then issued a letter criticizing tactics of some anti-abortion protesters as demeaning and lacking compassion. The letter also said people who call themselves ``pro-choice'' should not necessarily be considered pro-abortion. Weakland said he considered the Vatican's actions confusing and has written a letter asking for clarification. ``Everybody's shrugging their shoulders wondering what's going on,'' he said. He added that he knows church leaders have warned that his views ``are not without theological implications.'' ``It won't change my procedure, I'm sure, in dealing with any topic,'' he said. ``I'm not concerned about that.'' Weakland was to be one of of several honorary degree recipients at the ceremonies this week. He was to be honored for authoring a 1986 U.S. bishops' letter on the economy and social justice. The university canceled the awards ceremony rather than exclude him.

DOC.HEAD: Policemen Killed in Gang Battle in Southern Japan
DOC.TEXT: An intensifying gang war in southern Japan has killed two undercover policemen and wounded a passerby, officials said today. The two officers, shot Friday, were found in a car parked outside a golf center in a quiet residential area on the outskirts of Naha, on the island of Okinawa. The two policemen, who had been investigating a 3-month-old war between two rival criminal gangs, were shot in the head and died almost instantly, a police official said on condition of anonymity. During the gunbattle, Masako Sawada, 49, was injured in her left leg by bullets that ripped through her car as she and her husband drove through the quiet neighborhood. Police said the National Police Agency is sending its chief investigator to the area to look into the murders. The Kyodo News Service reported that Okinawa police have set up a 700-member squad to investigate the murders. Police quoted witnesses as saying that two men, who appeared to be members of the yakuza, Japan's underworld gangs, approached the policemen's parked car and fired their guns at close range. They shot at Mrs. Sawada's car while fleeing in another car. It was not immediately known if the suspected gang members meant to kill the officers, or if they thought they were members of the rival gang. Friday's murders were the latest in a gang war that has smoldered since September, when a larger gang split into two smaller groups after an internal dispute. Two gang members were shot and killed in October, and on Thursday a 19-year-old high school student was shot to death. Newspapers said the student was apparently mistaken for a gang member. Police say that since September, there have been 28 incidents involving gang shootings on Okinawa. Handguns are illegal in Japan, and though gangsters keep a high profile, violent crimes are relatively rare. Police estimate there are nearly 90,000 gangsters in Japan. A gang war in Tokyo drew heavy police and media attention earlier this year. The total underworld income - mostly from the sale of drugs, extortion and gambling - is believed to exceed $9 billion annually.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Says Salvadoran Rebels Shot Down Jet
DOC.TEXT: In the first incident of its kind in the 11-year-old civil war, the government says leftist rebels shot down one of its war jets with a missile. The downing Friday, which killed the pilot and wounded another crewman, came three days after the rebels launched an offensive that has killed nearly 100 people. The rebels say their offensive was aimed at forcing the rightist government of President Alfredo Cristiani back to the bargaining table after a series of stalemated sessions. A government communique on Friday claimed that rebel use of missiles in several attacks demonstrates that the rebels' past participation in peace talks ``is purely tactical.'' The fighter-bomber was shot down in eastern Usulatan province, the communique said. It said the A-47 Dragonfly was struck by a Soviet-designed missile at midday near Santa Elena, about 80 miles east of San Salvador. Earlier, the armed forces press office had said the plane crashed because of mechanical failure. It was the first time the government has said one of its warplanes was downed by a missile in El Salvador's civil war, a conflict that has cost at least 73,000 mostly civilian lives since it began in 1979. The United Nations is mediating peace talks between the government and the rebels. Five rounds of talks since May have produced little progress. A bill passed recently by the U.S. Congress cut in half the $85 million in military aid that El Salvador receives annually beginning in fiscal 1991. The legislation is aimed at forcing both sides to reach agreement on ending the war. It stipulates that the aid could be restored if the rebels launched an offensive that threatened to overthrow the government, or be halted altogether if President Cristiani's government refuses to negotiate. The government communique, broadcast Friday night, claimed the missile was one of several supplied to the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front rebels - also known as FMLN - by the leftist Sandinista government in neighboring Nicaragua before it relinquished power April 25. Such weapons represent ``extremely dangerous acts that could affect the political stability of the country,'' the communique said, adding that the rebels have been employing the missiles ``for the past 72 hours.'' Earlier Friday, the government said the rebels agreed to end an offensive they launched last Tuesday that killed at least 91 people. But a rebel spokesman denied it, and reports of new fighting surfaced. According to government officials, the offensive has killed 39 soldiers, 44 rebels and eight civilians and wounded about 300 people. The guerrillas claimed over their radio station that the army suffered 450 casualties, without saying how many were deaths. The foreign ministers of Mexico, Venezuela and Colombia, who were meeting in Mexico City on Friday, appealed for an end to the fighting and urged the two sides to cooperate with the U.N.-sponsored peace talks.

DOC.HEAD: Careening Truck Kills Five, Injures 17 in California Pileup
DOC.TEXT: A big-rig truck careened into stopped traffic, crumpling cars and flinging them aside in a fiery nine-car chain collision that killed five people and injured 17. The truck driver jumped from the cab moments before it burst into flames Friday morning, witnesses said. He was arrested to face manslaughter charges, California Highway Patrol dispatcher Cathy Cox said. ``He was traveling an unknown speed approaching stopped traffic at a signal,'' she said. ``Due to his speed, he was unable to stop.'' A car knocked into a pole and a pickup truck launched into a center divider carried the five people killed. The car became pinned under the truck and was dragged as the rig plowed seven other vehicles before coming to a halt and catching fire. The car and the pickup truck burned also. The empty grain truck partially melted in the inferno that forced closure of a rural stretch of Interstate 215 for nine hours. ``I don't know if the driver fell asleep or what,'' said Charlene Phillips, 53, whose car suffered slight damage in the pileup. ``I'm very, very lucky to be alive.'' Injuries ranged from one man hospitalized in serious condition to cuts and bruises. Moreno Valley is in Southern California about 65 miles east of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Turns Off Radar Because of Computer Errors
DOC.TEXT: A ground control computer error prompted the Magellan spacecraft to briefly halt its mapping expedition of Venus, but NASA officials said the probe remained in contact with Earth. The computer glitch occurred late Friday night. The multimillion-dollar craft was expected to resume its charting mission early today, NASA said in a statement. Magellan stopped mapping when an onboard computer detected errors in commands being sent from ground control computers, NASA said. It was the second report of problems with the craft's mapping mission in eight days. The Magellan signal was lost for 40 minutes on Nov. 15. Signals were lost twice in August. Flight controllers said some mapping orbits would be lost, but the craft did not lose contact with Earth. Engineers have lost contact with Magellan three times for reasons not yet fully understood, but believed to be electric static interfering with a spacecraft computer. Magellan was launched from Space Shuttle Atlantis on May, 4, 1989. It went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 and formally started its $744 million mapping mission Sept. 15. Magellan uses radar to map terrain through thick clouds covering Venus. It has sent back pictures of the planet's fractured volcanic surface, revealing numerous lava flows, volcanoes, quake faults and Los Angeles-sized meteorite impact craters.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Holiday Turkeys Tossed Out After Cyanide Scare
DOC.TEXT: Thanksgiving turkeys by the thousands were dumped in a landfill after a man started a holiday scare with claims he injected some of the birds with cyanide. Health officials said Friday they had received no reports of poisonings, and police said they had no evidence that any turkeys actually were laced with cyanide. The scare began the day before Thanksgiving when a man called KOLD-TV newswoman Barbara Grijalva and said he had injected some turkeys at Smith's Food and Drug stores in Tucson with cyanide. KOLD producer Rob Daniels said the caller said he ``had a problem with Smith's'' and poisoned the turkeys to ``prove a point.'' ``It appears to be simply the work of a hoax of a very sick person who either has a grudge to bear against Smith's or only wished to cause a great deal of anguish among innocent people on what should be one of our most joyous holidays,'' said Jeff Smith, chairman of the store chain. Smith's offered refunds or exchanges to 4,050 people who returned turkeys, some of which had been cooked. Employees pulled another 550 birds from the shelves. Smith's spokesman Jim Acton said the scare could cost the chain of stores as much as $200,000. Samples from several turkeys have been turned over to the national Centers for Disease Control for testing, he said. County health officials received no reports of people complaining of symptoms associated with cyanide poisoning, said James Robertson, environmental health director.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Circulation Of Bomb Photo Delayed Till After The Bombing
DOC.TEXT: British authorities failed to circulate photographs of a bomb in a cassette player before the downing of Pan Am Flight 103 because of delay in reproducing the pictures, an official says. Police believe a similar bomb blew up the Boeing 747 over Lockerbie, Scotland on Dec. 21, 1988, killing 270 people. James Jack, aviation security director of the British Department of Transport, also said Friday that nine security bulletins his agency received before the bombing were not specific enough to issue a major alert. Jack, speaking before an inquiry in the southern Scottish town of Dumfries, said his agency received photographs of the cassette player bomb 13 days before the bombing of Flight 103. But he said his agency failed to send the photographs to airlines and security staff until 17 days after the downing because of the time it took to reproduce them. ``I don't wish to divert responsibility for this matter. Perhaps if I had attached an urgent label or taken them round to the photographic department myself it would have been done in six hours. But I put them into a process and unfortunately it was a delayed one,'' he testified. Jack did not say who gave him the pictures. Families of victims have said previously that the warning photos were distributed by German authorities after German police discovered a bomb inside a radio cassette recorder during a raid on suspected terrorists. Jack responded to the widow of one of the Flight 103 victims, who inquired about nine security bulletins from governments, airlines or security sources that were not circulated before the bombing. ``That people have been arrested and a device has been impounded, is that a threat? That there has been a report that someone has perhaps tested procedure at an airline check-in desk, is that a threat?'' he asked. ``That there is information that two terrorists are about in Europe with a bomb, I hear about this frequently,'' he added without elaborating. ``The judgment about whether these represent a threat and certainly a specific threat is not as clear as you suggest,'' he told Mrs. Elizabeth Delude-Dix, whose husband Peter died in the bombing. Jack said that in 1988, he received reports of between 175 and 200 bomb threats against airlines operating flights from British airports. Last year, the figure was about 300, he said. Relatives of some of the victims have alleged that authorities failed to notify airline passengers about the pre-Lockerbie warnings and that if they had done, people would not have flown in Flight 103. Focused on the cause of the disaster, the inquiry opened last month and is expected to last into next year. More testimony is scheduled for Monday. Scottish investigators have said they are investigating several radical Palestinian groups, but the inquiry is not considering criminal responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Upstate New York and Northern Michigan
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell in upstate New York and northern Michigan early today. Skies were mostly clear elsewhere. Winds gusting to 100 mph knocked down power lines in Montana and started brush fires that threatened homes, authorities said. High winds also closed highways in western Washington and caused dust storms in the eastern half of the state while rains posed a new risk of flooding. The National Weather Service warned of possible floods today in western Washington, but rain-swollen rivers were expected to drop by Sunday as temperatures fall, the weather service said. Showers were expected in western Montana. Low pressure bulding in Maine was expected to bring rain to much of the state and snow in the mountains. Sunshine was the forecast for the rest of the East, the South and the Midwest. Snow was possible in northern Minnesota. Sunshine and warm temperatures were expected in the Rockies and the Southwest. Temperatures were expected to reach the 20s and 30s from Maine to Montana, the 40s in the Pacific Northwest and Ohio Valley, the 50s across much of the Northeast, the 60s in the Midwest, Rockies and Northern California, the 70s in the South and Southern California and the 80s in the Southwest. The high temperature for the nation Friday was 87 degrees at Brownsville, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Geneva Police Spokesman Says Bush Press Corps Was Rowdy, Not Swiss Police
With PM-Bush-Swiss
DOC.TEXT: A police spokesman today blamed members of the White House press corps for scuffles in which Swiss security officers jabbed a U.S. diplomat with a machine gun and roughed up a news photographer. Swiss government officials could not immediately be reached for comment on the incidents, which occurred during President Bush's three-hour stop in Geneva on Friday. Bush's spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, citing ``brutal and vicious treatment,'' said the United States planned to file a protest with the Swiss government. U.S. officials told reporters on the presidential plane that Swiss security officers shoved a machine gun into the stomach of American chief of protocol Joseph Reed and roughed up a traveling photographer of the French news agency Agence France-Presse. Geneva police spokesman Thierry Magnin today said an investigation of the affair is under way. But he said some American reporters ``behaved in a deplorable, inadmissible way. ``They did not respect security measures taken by Geneva police ... or Swiss territorial sovereignty, he said in a telephone interview. ``There certainly was a row and heated words, but this was to enforce security measures ... taken in accord with the American security services,'' Magnin said. One police officer at Geneva airport Friday night said the White House press corps behaved like ``occupying troops.'' Magnin said he could not comment on the machine gun incident. ``But if it happened, the submachine gun certainly was not pointed at the diplomat,'' he added. He said the police were simply doing their job and noted they have long experience with dignitaries coming through Geneva. ``There's no misconduct. On the contrary, they did their job well,'' he said. Tension between the White House party and Swiss security flared already at Bush's arrival for a hastily arranged meeting with Syria's President Hafez Assad. White House pool reporters, who arrived on a separate chartered plane, called the arrival ``a complete zoo, with Swiss officials winning the award as the worst hosts of the trip.'' Security personnel prevented the Washington reporters from getting close to Bush's plane when he arrived. A White House official said Swiss police, minutes before the arrival, changed media coverage arrangements agreed earlier with U.S. security officials. Magnin denied this, saying the arrangements had been clearly set earlier in the day.

DOC.HEAD: China Keeps Secret Its Stance on Use of Force in Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As President Bush lobbies world leaders for support of a U.N. resolution allowing the use of force in the Persian Gulf, China still refuses to show its hand. As a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, China has veto power and has refrained from using it on any of the 10 resolutions already in effect against Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But China's consistent refusal to clarify its position on the proposed U.N. resolution casts some doubt on the outcome of the vote. Official reports today of a meeting between Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen and his Soviet counterpart, Eduard Shevardnadze, again failed to reveal how China would vote. The Soviet Union, also a permanent Security Council member, has indicated support for the resolution. A joint statement released belatedly from the Friday meeting said, ``Both sides stand for a political solution to the gulf crisis on the basis of relevant U.N. Security Council resolutions .... They strongly appeal to Iraq and demand that it withdraw its army from Kuwait unconditionally and immediately. ``They hold that so far as there is still hope for a peaceful solution, the international community should continue to work to that end and try its best to avoid a war,'' it said. China has repeatedly avoided making clear how it will vote on the use-of-force measure. During an eight-day tour of the Middle East this month, Qian did not disclose China's intentions, and repeated questions to the Chinese Foreign Ministry have been answered with the standard call for a peaceful solution. By doing so, it has won praise and recouped international prestige lost after Beijing's military crackdown on a massive pro-democracy movement last year. Bush said Friday in Cairo he was confident the resolution would be approved. He met with Arab leaders in th Middle East after lobbying heads of state attending a 34-nation peace summit in Paris earlier this week. China's most recent statement, made today by Qian's assistant, Xu Dunxin, indicated that Bush's globetrotting efforts have not impressed the Chinese. Xu, attending a conference on the Cambodia issue in Paris, said that as long as a ``gleam of hope of peaceful solutions'' exists, the international community should continue efforts for a peaceful resolution, the official Xinhua News Agency reported.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Medical Device Stolen, Recovered
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to Update with device recovered. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police today recovered a stolen truck carrying an expensive nuclear medical device. The nuclear magnetic resonance machine was bound for a hospital in Catania, Sicily, when a group of men forced the driver to stop on an exit ramp near Catania on Friday and later left him on a highway. The truck was found early today about 12 miles outside Catania. Police said the nuclear device was untouched. The maker of the machine, NV Philips of the Netherlands, had warned the device could have ``consequences for personal safety'' if tampered with. Local police speculated the thieves were ``ordinary delinquents'' and were not seeking the device, which gives X-ray-like images by monitoring protons and neutrons in the body. The machine usually costs more than $1.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Berkeley Working on Plan for Urban Campsites for Homeless
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to move up `lifestyle' quote, CORRECT `less' to `fewer' in 3rd graf. Picks up 4th graf, `Brown said...'.
DOC.TEXT: Homeless people who are that way because they like a ``free and easy lifestyle'' could soon have the chance to pitch tents on vacant lots turned into urban campsites, an official said. Under a plan slated for City Council action in December or January, authorities would provide bathrooms and supervise the fenced camps 24 hours a day, City Manager Michael Brown said. The camps would be limited to groups of 25 people or fewer. Drugs and alcohol would be banned. Brown said many of the city's approximately 1,200 homeless people who don't want to change would benefit. ``They don't like shelters. They don't want remedial help. They don't want a job or job training,'' Brown said. ``They want a free and easy lifestyle and they would like a campground.'' City staff will begin looking for available vacant lots soon and once potential sites are found, the neighborhoods would be canvassed to explain the program and allow residents to comment, officials said. The city houses up to 220 street people nightly in shelters and has an annual $600,000 budget for homeless services, said Eric Landes-Brenman, Berkeley's homeless coordinator.

DOC.HEAD: Draft of New Union Treaty Published in Soviet Press
DOC.TEXT: The public got its first full look at President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plans for sharing power with the 15 Soviet republics today when major newspapers published a draft of his proposed union treaty. The proposed treaty represented the central government's latest attempt to appease secession movements by the republics and smaller regions while creating a uniform, market-oriented economic system. At a news conference Friday night, Gorbachev warned that a breakup of the Soviet Union could lead to ``bloodshed and civil conflict'' and said he would use all his constitutional powers to prevent it. Publication of the draft treaty gave the public its first glimpse of the proposal in full, designed as a charter for a new ``Union of Sovereign Soviet Republics.'' The draft has already been submitted to the Supreme Soviet legislature and the parliaments of the republics. To date, all but one of the republics, Kirgizia, have declared some form of sovereignty. The three Baltic states - Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania - have declared independence and say they will not sign a new union treaty. But they say they are willing to reach political and economic agreements with the Soviet Union and other republics. The legislature of a fourth republic, Georgia, on Friday ``uninamously enacted a law declaring a period of transition in the republic pending the restoration of its complete national independence and sovereignty,'' the newspaper Pravda reported today. During the transition, Pravda said, ``the parliament of Georgia regards the signing of a new union treaty as impossible.'' At his news conference, Gorbachev made it clear that republics wanting to leave the union must hold a referendum, as required under existing Soviet law. He said he would oppose any other form of dissolving the union. ``If someone tried to impose such a policy, it would result in bloodshed and civil conflict, which would be unacceptable to the world community,'' he said. Many of the treaty's points were unveiled by Gorbachev in the Supreme Soviet last weekend, and legislators twice endorsed his proposals to reorganize the central government to carry out the treaty. The draft provides for establishing the Council of the Federation, which would consist of a vice president, the first in Soviet history, and heads of the republics. The council would ``determine the main directions of the union's domestic and foreign policies,'' the Tass news agency said. The treaty also would create a presidential Cabinet, formed in agreement between the president and the Surpeme Soviet, Tass said. The Cabinet would replace the current Council of Ministers, headed by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. Under the draft treaty, each republic, ``as a sovereign state, has full state powers over its territory. Treaty participants regard the Soviet Union as a sovereign federative state formed as a result of the republics' voluntary union.'' Republics would ``independently determine their state structure, administrative-territorial division and the system of the bodies of power and administration,'' the draft says. In defining the sharing of power between the Kremlin and the republics, the draft treaty proclaimed, ``the supremacy of republic legislation over republics' territories on all questions, except those which are referred to the jurisdiction of the union.'' The central government would be empowered to adopt a new constitution, protect the country's borders and ensure the state's security. The Kremlin would continue to control the armed forces and be responsible for defense matters, the space program, railway, air and sea travel, and the administration of the fuel and energy system. The Kremlin would also determine the country's economic development and ``the creation of conditions for the development of the all-union market.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Iraq Still Producing Poison Gas
^With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is still producing poison gas and other military equipment with foreign help, despite the trade sanctions imposed by the United Nations, the German newsmagazine Der Spiegel reported today. Spiegel, quoting former German hostages recently released by Iraq and intelligence sources, said Iraqi plants in Samarra were producing 880 pounds daily of Tabun and Lost, two nerve gases. German and other Western experts were helping Iraq keep up production at military facilities, including those where Western hostages are being held as ``human shields'' to deter attack by multinational forces, Spiegel said. Western experts and salesmen travel are still traveling to Iraq via Amman, Jordan, to conclude lucrative military contracts, the report said. They have been guaranteed unhindered travel out of Iraq, Spiegel said. Spiegel's report was released to other news media in advance of its publication on Monday. Iraq is known to have a large arsenal of chemical weapons. In previous reports, Spiegel has said that six poison gas factories in Samarra, north of Baghdad, had been built with German help. The U.N. Security Council imposed the trade embargo on Iraq in response to Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. About 350,000 troops from 26 nations have been deployed in the gulf region to try to force Iraq out of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Tories Under New Leadership Would Win Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with new poll; Pickup 13th, `Supporters of...'
DOC.TEXT:
Amid charges that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was undermined by her own party, an opinion poll released today indicated three candidates for her job would bring the Conservatives an election victory. Under Mrs. Thatcher's leadership, the governing party had trailed Labor in opinion polls for 16 months. Labor is the main opposition party in Parliament. But a poll of about 1,100 voters Friday found that more voters preferred either former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine or Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major, to Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd would put the Tories neck and neck with Labor, with Hurd having a slight edge, according to the poll, taken by ICM for the Sunday Correspondent newspaper. The poll was published today. Forty-seven percent of people asked would vote for Heseltine, compared with 38 percent who would vote Labor, according to the poll of 1,139 people. Major received 46 percent of the vote, compared with 39 percent for Labor, and Hurd had 43 percent of the vote, compared with Labor's 41 percent, the poll showed. No margin of error was given. No poll can be 100 percent accurate, however, and there is usually a margin of error of at least two or three percentage points with a sample of that size, poll watchers said. The 372 Conservative Party members of the House of Commons will vote for a leader on Tuesday. If none of the three candidates receives a majority, a third ballot will be held Thursday. Mrs. Thatcher resigned on Thursday, after it appeared she would lose a Conservative Party leadership vote to Haseltine, who had made a strong showing in a first round of leadership balloting last Tuesday. Hurd and Major, Cabinet ministers no longer shackled by loyalty, immediately jumped into the leadership contest with Heseltine. The latest poll is similar to the findings of a Harris poll released Friday by Independent Television News that also predicted an upturn in Conservative Party fortunes under a new prime minister. That poll, of 1,107 voters on Thursday, found that the Conservatives, with any of the three candidates as leader, would beat Labor if a general election were held immediately. A general election must be held before mid-1992. The poll found voters ranked the candidates in the same order - with Heseltine leading Labor by 10 points, Major by seven points and Hurd by four. No margin of error was given in the Harris poll.
Supporters of the 65-year-old Mrs. Thatcher have angrily accused Conservatives of what one called ``political matricide'' in forcing her to quit after 15 years as party leader and 11{ years as prime minister. High inflation, rising interest rates, an unpopular new tax and her lone opposition among European Community leaders to financial and political integration were among factors that undermined her support. Cabinet colleagues and campaign managers told her she could not muster enough support to win in further balloting next week. Her opponents in the party feared that under her continuing leadership the Conservatives would lose to Labor at the next general election. Labor has been in opposition since 1979. Conservative legislators returning home for the weekend were met Friday by anger from grass-roots backers of Mrs. Thatcher. Peter Stainforth, local Conservative Party treasurer at Stevenage, about 25 miles north of central London, reported particular rancor over Sir Geoffrey Howe. The deputy prime minister quit on Nov. 1 and bitterly attacked Mrs. Thatcher in a Commons speech on Nov. 13. ``I cannot express how the constituency feels about that latter-day Brutus who was the first to plunge his dagger into his leader's back,'' Stainforth said.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Tops Bush Agenda With Mexican Leader
DOC.TEXT: President Bush meets with Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari on Monday, intent on providing impetus for what both countries hope will be a new era of cross-border economic activity. High on the agenda for the sixth meeting between Bush and Salinas in two years will be a proposed U.S.-Mexican free trade agreement that would complement a similar pact the United States reached with Canada in 1988. Bush and Salinas will meet in the northern Mexican city of Monterrey where, aside from formal talks, time has been set aside during Bush's 28-hour stay for a rodeo, abarbecue and a fireworks display. Salinas also has an ancestral home nearby which Bush will visit. Bush is plunging ahead with relish on the effort to forge a free trade agreement, telling the Mexican news agency Notimex in an interview published Thursday, ``We want to do it as soon as possible.'' During a June meeting in Washington, Bush and Salinas said a free trade agreement (FTA) would be a ``powerful engine for economic development, creating new jobs and opening new markets.'' FTA advocates say a booming Mexico would slow illegal emigration to the United States - estimated to be as much as 2 million entries a year - and create a lucrative markets for U.S. exports. But critics warn that an FTA could touch off an exodus of jobs from the United States to Mexico and its lower wage labor markets. Some in the administration predict a trade agreement could be in hand within a year, while others are looking to 1992 as a more likely timetable. Unless Congress rules otherwise, formal talks on transforming economic ties along the 2,000-mile border will get under way in the spring. The Monterrey talks also will touch on U.S. concerns about a dramatic upswing in transshipments of Colombian cocaine through Mexico. Mexico continues to be the largest foreign source of marijuana sold in the United States and one of the largest sources of heroin. However, a new State Department report says there has been a significant increase in drug enforcement activities by Mexican authorities over the past two years. Although corruption continues to be a problem, the report says Mexico has seized record amounts of drugs in the two-year period. But the prospective trade agreement will be the main topic at the Monterrey talks. The concept has been endorsed by private groups such as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the Bilateral Commission on the Future of U.S.-Mexican Relations and the Mexico-United States Institute. The benefits are obvious for Mexico, which sits adjacent to what is perhaps the largest market in the world: 300 million mostly prosperous Americans and Canadians. Salinas is banking on the notion that the rivers of technology and investment which have bypassed Mexico over the years, going instead to Asia and recently to Eastern Europe, will flow into his country once a free trade area extending from the Yukon to the Yucatan is in place. Particularly attractive to potential investors is the relatively low wage scale Mexico offers compared with the United States and Canada. As an example, a U.S. government study shows that the average hourly wage at foreign operated assembly plants along the Mexican side of the U.S. border is $1.63 compared with $14.32 in the United States. Some in the United States warn that the American workers will be big losers under an FTA. Rep. Don J. Pease, D-Ohio, a member of the House Ways and Means Trade subcommittee, wonders whether an FTA will have a depressing effect on U.S. wages. ``One certainly suspects so,'' Pease says. ``This is the kind of issue that needs to be addressed extensively and soon.''

DOC.HEAD: Deploying to Saudi Arabia: Only Slightly Less Daunting This Time
DOC.TEXT: When it hauled a million tons of bullets and beans to the Persian Gulf at the outset of Operation Desert Shield, the Pentagon likened the task to moving a city the size of Chattanooga, Tenn., halfway around the world. It's moving time again, but with a European twist. Half of all U.S. Army forces in Europe, with hundreds of 63-ton battle tanks, artillery pieces, rocket launchers and tons of other heavy equipment, are heading for the Saudi desert to reinforce the 230,000 U.S. troops there. The exact number of Army reinforcements is secret but probably near 100,000. It ranks as the biggest U.S. military exodus from Europe since the end of World War II. Some of the Army's Apache helicopters already have traveled the Rhine River by barge to major ports in Belgium, Holland and Germany where they are being loaded aboard ``fast sealift'' ships for a nine-day voyage to the Arabian Peninsula. The troops will follow later, although departure dates have not been set, said Sgt. J.D. Hardesty, a spokesman at U.S. Army Europe headquarters in Heidelberg, Germany. They'll be joined by more than 20,000 Navy sailors now gearing up to steam to the gulf, 45,000 Marines from across the United States, at least 16,500 members of the Army's ``Big Red One'' 1st Infantry Division (Mechanized) from Fort Riley, Kan., and thousands of military reservists called up to support the new deployments. It's a logistical challenge on a scale topped only by the first wave of American deployments to the gulf, which itself was the largest short-notice military airlift and sealift in American history, according to the Defense Department. The first wave of Desert Shield deployments all started from the United States. This time the job should be less daunting, because of the benefit of lessons learned from the first go-round and because of the shorter distance the heavy armored units in Europe and their supplies will have to travel. And because a large defensive U.S. force already is in Saudi Arabia, speed of transport is less critical than in the early stages of the crisis, when U.S. officials feared that Iraqi forces might make a run at the Saudi oil fields. So equipment this time can be moved entirely by sea rather than rushed by air. On the other hand, the task is complicated by the fact that it must take place at the same time spare parts and other supplies are flowing into the gulf for the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps units already deployed there. President Bush's decision in August to send U.S. troops to the gulf caught military logistics planners off guard. And while few people foresaw that Bush on Nov. 8 would order as many as 200,000 additional troops to go, the transportation commands say they were ready. ``Sealift ships began moving toward loading ports within hours of the president's announcement,'' said a Military Sealift Command official who asked not to be identified. ``We are not beginning the second lift from a standing start.'' Tricia Larson, a Sealift Command spokeswoman, said about 160 sealift ships are operating now, including seven ``fast sealift'' vessels that can travel at 33 knots, and 41 slower cargo ships activated from the Ready Reserve Fleet, a sort of 96-ship navy-in-waiting that is used in emergencies. The Pentagon also has been forced to charter 59 cargo ships, of which 45 are flying foreign flags, and 22 petroleum tankers, of which five are foreign-flagged, Ms. Larson said. The Marine Corps is mobilizing Marine Prepositioning Ship Squadron 1 from Norfolk, Va. The unit consists of five ships that carry tanks, trucks, armored vehicles, fuel, food and other supplies to keep 16,500 Marines combat ready for 30 days. Most U.S. troops will be flown to Saudi Arabia by commercial airliners, as happened during the initial buildup when, for the first time ever, the U.S. Transportation Command mobilized the Civil Reserve Air Fleet. That in effect meant the Pentagon commandeered a fleet of 29 U.S. commercial airliners for its own use. Sgt. Scott Leas, a spokesman for the Military Airlift Command at Scott Air Force Base, Ill., said the commercial aircraft are still at the Pentagon's disposal. He said it was too early to say whether extra commercial jets would be needed. ``It's all in the planning stage,'' he said. The Military Airlift Command is expected to use most of its fleet of military cargo planes, which includes 127 C-5 Galaxies for large and heavy cargo, 266 C-141 Starlifters for less bulky, lighter-weight vehicles and equipment and 660 smaller C-130 Hercules.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Says Vatican, Vietnam On Path to Conciliation
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Saturday said the Vatican and Vietnam are moving toward reconciliation and he is hopeful the church can achieve full freedom in the Communist country. ``In a climate of mutual respect, understanding and good will, a dialogue has begun which augurs well for the future,'' the pope said in a speech to 21 visiting Vietnamese bishops. John Paul said he based his assessment on the results of a visit to Vietnam earlier this month by an official Vatican delegation. Cardinal Roger Etchegary, head of the Vatican's Justice and Peace Commission, held talks with officials in Hanoi and elsewhere on church-state issues. ``The road will still be long and the difficulties will not be lacking, but it seems that it is the right path,'' the pope said in French. ``I hope that in the near future the Vietnamese church finds that the place which it deserves in society is ever more recognized.'' ``Be assured,'' he told the bishops, ``that the Holy See will do all in its power so that these first steps in dialogue can lead to an understanding which brings lasting fruit for the good of the church of Vietnam.'' There are an estimated 4 to 5 million Catholics among Vietnam's largely Buddhist population of 63 million. While restrictions on Catholics and other believers have eased in recent years, several problems with the Vatican remain. One major issue is the appointment of archbishops for vacant posts in Hanoi, Hue and Ho Chi Minh City. In his address to the pope, the head of the Vietnamese bishops' conference lamented that bishops are lacking in five dioceses and that there are virtually no priests in northern Vietnam. Monsignor Paul Marie Nguyen Minh Nhat, bishop of Xuan Loc in southern Vietnam, said authorities continue to restrict the number of seminary students, the activities of religious congregations and the availability of religious education. ``The difficulties are multiplying with time, as the needs of the community increase and the missionary personnel decreases,'' he said. The pope said the Vietnamese church is suffering from a shortage of priests and an aging clergy. He said he hoped priestly candidates finishing seminary studies ``will be able to be ordained freely and begin their ministry as soon as possible.'' According to a church report last year, only 15 priests have been ordained since the communist takeover in 1975. John Paul noted that Vietnam has only four seminaries, with two others scheduled to open soon. ``I fervently hope that no obstacle is put in the way and that you can receive the candidates in these centers without any limitation on their numbers,'' he said. Two years ago, the Hanoi government protested the pope's canonization of 117 martyrs killed in Vietnam in the 18th and 19th centuries. The pope said visiting bishops were in Rome to pay tribute to the martyred saints. ``It is moving to think that you live your episcopal ministry under the patronage of these saints,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: In a story Friday about the Irish government's attempts to recover a Bronze Age necklace, The Associated Press erroneously reported that the object will be auctioned by Christie's. The auctioneers were contacted by a private party who claims ownership, but there are no plans for an auction, said Christie's spokesman Mark Wrey.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats Use Unseen `Ears' To Try To Raise Gulf War Fears
DOC.TEXT: Western diplomats, acutely aware of hidden microphones, are talking to the walls in Baghdad. They hope to send the message that the threat of war is real and that the result will be devastating. It's not that Iraq's leaders believe President Bush is bluffing, the diplomats say. They recognize there's a danger of war. But they remain confident they can outlast the threat, the sanctions and the international coalition aligned against them. ``We're trying to convince them that it's real and imminent,'' a Western diplomat said. ``We're trying to show them what they're facing. We're walking around talking to the walls, telling them about B-52 strikes.'' ``We talk about our own fears and hope the message is passed along'' to President Saddam Hussein's inner circle by the Iraqi intelligence agencies bugging them. Saddam will not back down or withdraw from Kuwait as long as he believes he can withstand the embargo, break the international will behind it and forestall attack with clever hostage releases and behind-the-scenes deals, the diplomats contend. The diplomats argue that Saddam now cannot afford to invade Kuwait and then just cave in to international pressure. The Iraqi people are already questioning why they fought for eight years with Iran only to give all the gains away after the invasion of Kuwait. So, the diplomats say, he plays for time, dealing with hostages and hinting to visiting delegations that perhaps, just perhaps, there's a chance to talk, to negotiate. Iraq's plan to release all its hundreds of foreign hostages in batches between Christmas and March 25 is cited as an example of how Iraq believes it can forestall attack. Iraqi officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, candidly admit that the threat of war is the highest between late December and March and that the hostage release is a manuever to delay Bush and weaken the American resolve to attack. The officials say they have tried other means, including attempts to talk with the Americans through back channel diplomatic contacts. But they say the Americans have never responded. People on the street in Baghdad seem less afraid of war then they did in late August and September when the allied troop buildup in Saudi Arabia was just beginning. ``There will be no war. America is a great country, a country that cares for its people. It won't waste their lives in a war,'' said one Baghdad resident, who asked to be identified only as Yousef. His sentiments were repeated often by other Iraqis and by some Indian and Moroccan workers who have elected to stay at their jobs in Iraq despite the crisis. Some Western diplomats say the public has been lulled to sleep by the Iraqi propaganda machine that daily prints stories of growing opposition to war in America and the West and growing world support for Saddam and the cause of peace. But other diplomats say that many in Iraq, who have benefited from some of Saddam's policies, are convinced he is a cunning and clever man who will prevent the war and survive the crisis. ``This is a republic of fear, no doubt,'' said one Asian diplomat. ``But it's also a country where the common man has benefited greatly. It's not a pyramid standing only on fear of Saddam Hussein.'' Despite the economic sanctions - spot shortages of some goods and soaring prices for others - many Iraqis believe the crisis is only a short-term inconvienence. ``America will never go to war over Kuwait,'' said one Baghdad, who gave his name as Ahmed. ``Why should it?'' For the most part, it's business as usual in Iraq. There are noisy wedding parties outside the big hotels and celebrations for prisoners of war repatriated from Iran. ``They know Iraq is a potentially very rich country,'' the Asian diplomat said. ``It's sitting on the world's second-largest reserves of oil.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Diplomat Found Slain
DOC.TEXT: A senior Iraqi diplomat who allegedly refused orders to return to Baghdad was found murdered in his car outside the capital, officials said Saturday. Moayed Arab Nouri, consul at the Iraqi Embassy and considered the No. 2 Iraqi diplomat in Rabat, was found dead in his car near Mehdia-Plage, 18 miles north of the capital, according to the Saudi Arabian newspaper Acarq al-Awsat. The report did not say when the killing took place. Officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed the report and said he died of blows from a blunt instrument. No further information was immediately available. According to the Saudi newspaper, Nouri refused an order to return to Baghdad and rented an apartment in the Moroccan capital, where he had been living with his wife and three children. The paper did not say when the diplomat was ordered home. Morocco has sided with fellow Arab nations such as Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia, strongly condemning the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: 20th Anniversary of Celebrated Novelist's Spectacular Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Twenty years after celebrated novelist Yukio Mishima's spectacular hara-kiri, the dream of a resurgent Japanese imperialism he died espousing seems as distant as ever. ``I can't think of a single lasting effect (his death) had,'' said Donald Richie, a cultural critic who has lived in Japan four decades. Mishima, regarded as one of the leading Japanese authors of this century, scandalized the nation when he committed ritual disembowelment at a Tokyo military base Nov. 25, 1970, at age 45. Just minutes before his suicide, Mishima and four young members of his small, private militia took a general hostage and demanded that troops stationed at the base hastily assemble on the parade ground. In a speech from a balcony parapet, he urged the soldiers to arms to regain glory for the Japanese military and the emperor. He also denounced the postwar constitution that renounces war and limits the emperor's role to state symbol. Ending his failed, heckled speech with the cry, ``Long live the emperor!'' Mishima hurried indoors, stripped to his loincloth and plunged a foot-long dagger into his lower abdomen, cutting crosswise. The horrific suicide ended when one of the youths decapitated Mishima with a sword. Japan had hardly seen such ritual suicide since the immediate aftermath of World War II, and there were immediate worries that Mishima's actions could help revive the militarism that launched the horrifying Pacific War. But his appeals went unheeded by all except a small fringe of right-wing extremists. Today, the revived militarism he advocated appears more unlikely than ever. The widespread opposition to a recent government proposal to deploy troops overseas for the first time since World War II ``certainly suggests that his notions of re-establishing the Imperial Army ... do not have popular support in the country,'' said J. Victor Koschmann, a visiting history professor at the Stanford Center in Kyoto. The lukewarm public interest in this month's enthronement of Emperor Akihito also indicates little support for reviving the prewar status of monarch as a ``living god'' to be fanatically worshipped. ``Other than a small fringe, for whom he's still a cult figure of sorts, I just don't think (Mishima) has that broad an appeal,'' Koschmann said. The anniversary is passing mostly in embarrassed silence, although one right-wing group will hold a rally Sunday to be followed by a march through Tokyo to the base where Mishima committed suicide. Only a few thousand are expected to attend. Some newspapers and magazines have carried articles and photographs on Mishima in the days before the anniversary, and at least six books on Mishima have been published recently. Mishima's novels, plays and short stories are known for reflecting the conflict between the encroaching West and traditional Japanese values, a conflict that Mishima felt intensely himself. The works often reveal an obsession with beauty, death and suicide. Among his best-known novels are ``Confessions of a Mask'' (1949), a partly autobiographical account of a boy's self-awakening that includes themes of homosexuality found in many of Mishima's later works. Another popular novel was ``The Temple of the Golden Pavilion'' (1956), an examination of what led an ugly young monk obsessed with the beauty of a Buddhist temple to burn it down. Mishima's works are widely studied among literature students at Japanese universities. ``I think that people like Mishima because his novels create a strong sense of Japanese traditional beauty,'' said Jiro Kawamura, a literature professor at the Tokyo Metropolitan University. ``He is a very problematic, important novelist, but I don't think he is a great novelist,'' said Kawamura. ``His work is full of rhetoric. He is not a genius.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Confident About Resolution On Force; Saddam Calls Up Reserves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Baker in Colombia, protest in Jordan, Spanish foreign minister comments; Edits to trim; No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CAI1,DHA1,2
DOC.TEXT: President Bush returned home today saying he is close to getting the support he needs for U.N. approval of force against Iraq, while Secretary of State James A. Baker III met on the gulf crisis with officials in Colombia. In Beijing, Spanish Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez said a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing force to Liberate Kuwait could be passed before the end of November. A day earlier, Britain's foreign secretary, Douglas Hurd, said the U.N. Security Council probably would meet next week to discuss the issue. It was the first indication enough support had been gathered for the measure. The Soviet Union's U.N. envoy also said Friday Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze would attend a Security Council meeting next week to discuss Iraqi aggression - and to issue a ``strong, serious and precise warning'' to Baghdad. Saddam Hussein called on his war-hardened reservists to help defend the emirate, which he invaded on Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, land and money. Bush and Baker have been lobbying world leaders on behalf of the use-of-force measure. Baker made a four-hour visit today to Bogota, Colombia, one of ten non-permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. He was on the last leg of a five-day whirlind tour of Security Council member states. But in meetings with Colombian President Cesar Gaviria Trujillo and other officials, he failed to gain support for a resolution on force. Colombian Foreign Minister Luis Jaramillo said Colombia has not yet decided how it would vote in a resolution approving force. ``Finding peaceful solutions to conflicts is a fundamental thesis within Colombia foreign policy,'' Jaramillo said at a joint news conference with Baker. However, he said Colombia stands firm with the world community in rejecting Iraqi aggression. Colombia has voted in favor of all previous Security Council resolutions on Iraq. The Spanish foreign minister said he believed a resolution on force would be passed by the end of November. ``I've always had the impression that it was possible such a resolution would pass this month,'' Fernandez Ordonez said after meeting with Chinese leaders in Beijing Today. He made it clear, however, that his view did not result from discussions with the Chinese. China has refused to say how it would vote on a possible resolution on military force. As one of the five permanent Security Council members, China has veto power over resolutions. The other permanent members are Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. But Bush said Friday he was confident he would get approval from the 15-member Security Council. There had been reports of disagreement between Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev when they met earlier this week in Paris. But Gorbachev denied that at a news conference Friday. ``I can tell you that meeting I had with President Bush only reinforced our cooperation,'' he said. He repeated his call for the Security Council to meet in the near future. In his latest meeting, Bush held talks in Geneva Friday with Syrian President afez Assad. Assad declined to tell reporters whether Syria would participate in any military offensive against Iraq. Syria has sent some 7,500 ground troops to participate in the multinational force against Iraq. It has promised 15,000. In Amman, Jordan, today the Parliament bitterly attacked Washington for intervening in the Gulf crisis and condemned Saudi Arabia for allowing Western troops on its soil. Pro-Iraqi sentiments run high in Jordan, which has a majority of Palestinians. They view Saddam as leading the struggle to liberate their homeland from Israeli occupation. About 26 nations have deployed some 350,000 troops in the gulf region, including 250,000 U.S. personnel. They face an estimated 460,000 Iraqi troops stationed in Kuwait and southern iraq. The latest Iraqi call-up, announced in a Defense Ministry communique broadcast on Baghdad radio, involves reservists in their 30s, including battle-tested veterans of the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. They apparently will be among 150,000 reservists and draftees that Iraq said earlier this week would be sent to Kuwait, along with about 100,000 other regular army troops. Since the Iraqi invasion, the United Nations has passed 10 resolutions against Baghdad, including a global trade embargo. Britain's Hurd told reporters in London that ``Soon, probably next week, the Security Council will consider a draft resolution authorizing member states to use force to bring about the reversal of the Iraqi aggression.'' The Soviet ambassador to the United Nations, Yuliy M. Vorontsov, also said the Security Council would meet next week to discuss Iraqi aggression, but did not specify whether the measure on force would be discussed. He said Shevardnadze would attend. The urgency is in part because Yemen, which has tilted toward Iraq in the past, takes over the rotating chairmanship of the Security Council from the United States in December.

DOC.HEAD: Statement From Aide Says DeConcini Referred to Memo in 1987 Meeting
DOC.TEXT: When Sen. Dennis DeConcini met with the nation's top thrift regulator in 1987, he made references to a memo that proposed a deal favorable to S&L owner Charles H. Keating Jr., according to a sworn statement before the Senate Ethics Committee. The question of whether the Arizona Democrat actually offered a deal on Keating's behalf is crucial to the ethics investigation of DeConcini and four Senate colleagues. DeConcini has repeatedly denied making such an offer. The sworn statement, given by someone who did not attend the 1987 meeting, says only that DeConcini made ``verbal references'' to a memo outlining a proposal for Keating. The ethics committee is trying to determine whether the so-called ``Keating Five'' improperly pressured S&L regulators on behalf of Keating - a major political donor. The other senators are John McCain, R-Ariz., Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., Alan Cranston, D-Calif. and John Glenn, D-Ohio. The sworn statement was given to the committee last August by Glenn's administrative assistant, Mary Jane Veno, and released last week. According to the affidavit, Ms. Veno told the committee what she learned from DeConcini's administrative assistant about the April 2, 1987 meeting between four senators (all except Riegle) and top regulator Edwin J. Gray. No Senate staffers attended the meeting. Ms. Veno said she was told about the memo by Gene Karp, who said Friday that his recollection of their conversation differs from hers. The 1987 meeting is important because Gray insists that DeConcini then offered a quid pro quo on Keating's behalf. Gray said an essential part of the offer was that Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan would offer more home mortgages if regulators would exempt Lincoln from a rule limiting risky investments. Committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett said in his opening statement the evidence shows that DeConcini offered the deal. But DeConcini has denied it in the strongest possible terms. And Cranston, Glenn and McCain back him on that point. In the sworn statement, Ms. Veno said that some time after allegations of a deal for Keating became public in late 1989, Karp called her at home. He ``explained that Sen. DeConcini had brought the memorandum with him to the April 2 meeting, and during the meeting, had made verbal references to the subjects discussed in the memorandum,'' she told the committee. The memorandum, dated March 19, 1987, was from DeConcini staffer Laurie A. Sedlmayr to her boss. It detailed ``What American Continental (Lincoln's parent company) wants from Gray for concessions'' and ``What American Continental is willing to do.'' Ms. Sedlmayr is scheduled to testify Monday when the committee resumes its hearings. Karp said Friday that since the 1987 meeting was held in DeConcini's office, the memo was available to the senator. But Karp said he did not know if DeConcini actually referred to it. In an interview, Karp said he could not recall exactly what he told Ms. Veno, but ``as I remember it now, Gray said at the very beginning he didn't know anything about Lincoln and DeConcini never got into the subject matter of the investigation or anything about that. Whether there was any specific reference made, I can't answer. Only the principals that were there can answer it.'' Karp added that he does not recall telling Ms. Veno that DeConcini made ``verbl references'' to the memo and ``I find it difficult to imagine that I said that.'' Ms. Veno could not be reached for comment on her statement or Karp's. The aides received information on the meetings from the senators, but had no firsthand knowledge, since only the four senators and Gray were in the room and no transcript of the session exists. Ms. Veno also said in her statement that when she queried Glenn about the April 2 meeting, the senator said he ``did not recall Sen. DeConcini making such statements (about a deal) nor did he believe such statements were made.'' But she added that Glenn also ``said it was possible that Sen. DeConcini raised this issue in his opening remarks at the meeting, and that Sen. Glenn was not focusing on Sen. DeConcini's comments at the time.'' The purpose of the fact-finding hearings, which began Nov. 15, is to decide whether any of the five senators improperly pressured regulators on behalf of Keating, who along with associates contributed $1.3 million to their campaigns and causes. Much of the money was donated while the businessman was fighting regulators during their intense investigation of Lincoln, the Irvine, Calif. thrift that was seized by the government in April 1989 at a potential bailout cost to taxpayers of more than $2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Sketches Of The Main Candidates in Poland Election
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are sketches of the main candidates in Poland's first direct democratic presidential election Sunday: --- LECH WALESA= The 47-year-old with an astonishing mix of political instinct and personal charisma has arguably done more than any other individual to topple Communism and says the presidency is his next responsiblity. He contends even more must be reformed if Poland is to become a true democracy. Born to a dirt-poor farm family in a remote hamlet, Walesa had a trade-school education when he drifted to the Baltic port of Gdansk and took a job at the Lenin shipyard in 1967. Increasingly incensed by the workers' lot and dispiriting totalitarian rule - especially after the bloody repression of strikes in 1970 - Walesa lost one job after another to his activism. He was unemployed and outside the strikebound shipyard when he made his famous leap over the gate to lead Solidarity's founding in 1980. Interned after martial law in December 1981 and awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1983, Walesa maneuvered the Solidarity movement through years of repression to its takeover of the government in 1989. After creating the Solidarity government, against dubious colleagues' advice, Walesa found himself on the political sidelines in Gdansk but increasingly alarmed by social discontent, apathy and disaffection with the new government. He can be autocratic and contradictory - demagogic, irresponsible and uncultured to his critics - but the Walesa of the twinkling eyes, mesmerizing speech, to-the-people style and enormous courage still holds immense sway. --- TADEUSZ MAZOWIECKI= The 63-year-old prime minister became Eastern Europe's first non-Communist government leader in August 1989, launched the region's most dramatic economic overhaul on Jan. 1, and says Poland needs his team to stay and finish the job. Mazowiecki's devout Catholicism led him to oppose the then-Communist government. During the 1950s, he founded the influential Club of Catholic Intellectuals in Warsaw and the monthly magazine, Wiez. In 1961, he joined the parliament delegation of ZNAK, a tiny officially condoned independent group protected by the church. But eventually his principles clashed with the Communists' bounds of tolerance. After he demanded an investigation into the 1970 killings of strikeing workers, he was barred from re-election. Mazowiecki joined Walesa in the founding days of Solidarity in August 1980. He brought a letter of support from intellectuals to the strikebound Gdansk shipyard, and stayed. Imprisoned during martial law, the taciturn lawyer negotiated with Communists in 1989 at historic talks and submitted the court motion winning back Solidarity's legal status. Proposed for prime minister by Walesa, Mazowiecki has become increasingly confident - though never comfortable - under the international spotlight. But the two split, along with the once-united Solidarity movement, over the whether Mazowiecki's deliberate, reasoned course to reform is too slow. --- STANISLAW TYMINSKI= The virtually unknown 42-year-old emigre with Polish, Canadian and Peruvian citizenship grabbed the spotlight late in the campaign when one poll showed him in second place, trailing only Walesa. Tyminski says he left Poland penniless 21 years ago, going first to Sweden as a tourist and then emigrating to Canada, where he became a millionaire. He started a cable television outfit and a restaurant in the Amazon port of Iquitos, Peru, and then returned to Canada, where he runs Transduction Ltd., a computer automation firm near Toronto. He leads the Libertarian Party of Canada, a fringe party that has no representative in parliament. Tyminski, financing his own campaign, attracted supporters disenchanted with Poland's drastic economic reforms who responded to his harsh criticism of the government. But his credentials went largely unchallenged until his surge in the polls. Then journalists started to question his long absence from Poland and state prosecutors launched a slander investigation after he accused Mazowiecki of treason against the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Saddam: I'm Not Bluffing
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, expressing growing impatience, appears grimly determined to show he is willing to go to war against Iraq to end its takeover of Kuwait. The resounding message of Bush's just-concluded trip through Europe and the Middle East was that time is running out for a peaceful retreat by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. For the first time, Bush raised the possibility of setting a deadline for Baghdad. He also spoke bluntly of ``a commitment to use force.'' And he offered a chilling justification for amassing military forces against Iraq, warning that Saddam was moving closer to building an arsenal of nuclear weapons. ``The world is getting tired of this,'' Bush declared of Iraq's nearly four-month occupation of Kuwait. Bush's theme was that he hopes for a peaceful resolution but is laying the foundation for possible war. He said he was not bluffing. Prodded by the United States, the United Nations Security Council is expected to meet within days on a measure authorizing force to remove Iraq. Bush said the United States is very close to winning U.N. approval. Even without it, he said, ``We have the authority to do what we have to do.'' Congress was uneasy about Bush's saber-rattling before his trip, and the hardening of his rhetoric is sure to raise new concerns. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole of Kansas said he would urge Congress to reconvene immediately if the United Nations endorsed a resolution on force. He said he hoped Congress also would endorse force. Bush made the Persian Gulf crisis the constant centerpiece of his eight-day trip to Czechoslovakia, Germany, a 34-nation summit in Paris, Saudi Arabia and Egypt. ``We're not walking away until our mission is done, until the invader is out of Kuwait,'' Bush told Marines and British ``Desert Rats'' during a Thanksgiving Day visit to a remote desert outpost in Saudi Arabia. ``And that may be where you come in.'' The 230,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf, and 200,000 more on the way, give real credence to the president's implied threat. Yet, despite Bush's resolve, there are signs of wear in the global coalition against Iraq and there is reluctance - or mixed signals - from some nations about the military option. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev counseled patience to allow diplomacy to work. So did German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, warning of the consequences of war. On the other hand, Margaret Thatcher ordered 14,000 more British troops to the gulf even as she announced her resignation as prime minister. Bush got public backing from Egypt and Saudi Arabia for using force, and Syria agreed that Iraq's aggression must not stand. However, there were divisions in the Arab world. Yemen, which will assume the rotating chairmanship of the Security Council in December, criticized the military buildup in the gulf and refused to endorse tougher action. Yemen's attitude is a key reason why Bush wants U.N. action before the end of the month when the United States has to relinquish the council chairmanship. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who has circled the globe in recent days lobbying for tougher action, cautioned against ``the siren song of partial solutions.'' And Baker said disapprovingly that some nations are beginning to talk of allowing Iraq to hold on to disputed islands in the gulf or be granted access to the gulf. ``So-called partial solutions are out of the question,'' Bush declared. Stopping in Cairo, Bush vowed, ``We're going to pull this coalition together. We're going to keep this coalition together and we're going to see what happens.'' Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, known for his caution, spoke gloomily about prospects for a peaceful ending. ``I am pessimistic,'' he said. ``I don't see the slightest movement'' by Saddam. If he needed it, Bush got encouragement for quick action from some of the American troops he visited in Saudi Arabia and aboard the amphibious assault ship USS Nassau in the Persian Gulf. ``We either want to fight or we want to go home,'' said Marine Lance Cpl. David Kimmel of Jonestown, Pa. ``I wish it would happen because I'm tired of being here,'' agreed Lance Cpl. Doug Mitchell of Hattiesburg, Miss. Troy Knapp, a 19-year-old corporal from Denver, said he thought Bush was looking for a military solution. ``You're going to wonder if he'll take the political heat for keeping the troops here for another five months,'' Knapp said. Bush told the troops: ``No American will be kept in the gulf a single day longer than necessary, but we won't pull punches. We are not here on some exercise. ... This is a real world situation.'' Bush has refused to specify how long he'll wait for sanctions to work against Iraq. But he said that at the United Nations, ``We'll be discussing not only the need to consider further action, but perhaps a time frame.''

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Flight Attendants Offered Free Flights for Not Calling In Sick
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines is offering flight attendants two free first-class tickets anywhere in the world for reporting as scheduled for holiday duty. It's an attempt to cut down on sick calls over the holidays. In a recent letter to workers, Northwest in-flight services chief Lloyd Warren thanked flight attendants in advance for reporting for holiday duty. And as ``a token of our thanks,'' Warren said, two free round-trip tickets in first-class seating would be given to flight attendants who report as scheduled between Dec. 15 and Jan. 1. Northwest employs more than 8,000 flight attendants. To qualify, workers must be scheduled for flights on Dec. 24, Dec. 25, Dec. 31 or Jan. 1. Service charges that normally accompany worker flight-pass privileges would be waived. Northwest spokesman Doug Miller said that last year, flight attendants were offered a $100 cash bonus for working through the holidays. Miller said the offer does not reflect a problem with holiday sick leave in the ranks of flight attendants. ``It's just that when we're in crunch time like we are around the holidays, every single person is key to our success,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Extremists Blamed for Landmine Attack, 5 Killed
DOC.TEXT: A land mine thought to have been planted by Sikh extremists exploded Saturday under a police jeep in Punjab, killing five policemen, a district official said. In another attack in the same district, Sikh gunmen herded five Hindus out of their homes shortly before midnight Friday and shot them outside their village, senior superintendent of police Narinder Pal Singh said. Sikh militants fighting for a separate nation in Punjab have killed about 2,930 people so far this year in the rich farming state on the Pakistani border. Singh said a land mine exploded Saturday morning as a police patrol traveled in three jeeps in Tarn Taran, 15 miles south of Amritsar. Police Superintendent Harjit Singh, his driver and three bodyguards were fatally wounded in the explosion, according to Narinder Pal Singh, who is in charge of the Tarn Taran district. In Patti, 25 miles south of Amritsar, eight or nine Sikh militants ordered five Hindus out of their homes at gunpoint late Friday night and forced them to walk to the edge of the village where they killed them, Singh said. All five were Hindus, he said. Four were shopkeepers, and the fifth was a member of the Home Guard, a local defense force. Sikh militants launched their violent campaign in 1982, saying they needed a separate nation for members of their faith. Sikhs have a slight majority over Hindus in Punjab, but nationwide they comprise only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. The militants accuse Hindus, who make up 82 percent of the national population, of discriminating against them economically and politically. Amritsar, home of the Golden Temple, the Sikh's holiest shrine, is in Amritsar. The Sikh faith has roots in both Hinduism and Islam.
