But once there is anatomical damage, surgery is the only answer, he said. ``She will be crippled for the rest of her life'' without surgery, he said. Thomas Moriarty, a spokesman for the state Department of Children and Youth Services, defended the agency's decision to intervene. ``Although this case has undertones of cultural and philosophical differences, we have to rely on what our doctors tell us,'' Moriarty said. ``The bottom line is - we have to protect children.''

DOC.HEAD: British, Italian, Greek Hostages To Be Freed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with announcement that Greeks, Germans to be freed, Finnish delegation arriving in Baghdad; no pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A group of British women on Saturday won the release of relatives held in Iraq's so-called human shield, and Saddam Hussein promised a Catholic priest that he would free ``a large number'' of Italians. Baghdad's official media announced the planned releases but did not say when the hostages would be allowed to leave. Greece said 10 hostages would be released Sunday. The Iraqi Embassy in Athens said Saddam ordered the release in response to an appeal by representatives of the Greek-Iraqi Friendship Association, currently visiting Baghdad. A German Foreign Ministery spokesman said German hostages freed by Iraq also were expected to return home on Sunday afternoon. The spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there were about 170 Germans left in Iraq and in Kuwait. Iraq has said that all German hostages would be allowed to leave, but the spokesman said he did not know how many would be on Sunday's flight. Hundreds of foreigners have been held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait in August. Some have been freed in return for shipments of food and medicines and others in an attempt to gain favor and divide the international coalition opposed to the invasion. Saddam met for one hour with the 10 British women, who flew to Baghdad last week seeking the release of their husbands, despite advice from the British government against the trip. Iraqi state television quoted Saddam as telling the women: ``Preventing British nationals from leaving is not our wish, but is one of the means to avert a bigger catastrophe.'' It did not say how many Britons would be allowed to leave, but that all of them ``are guests of the Iraqi people.'' That indicated the men are among more than 400 Britons held at strategic sites as human shields against a potential military attack. Iraq calls these hostages ``guests.'' They also include 200 other foreigners, mainly Americans and Japanese. In addition to the Britons held at about 30 installations in Iraq and occupied Kuwait, about 700 Britons also are banned from traveling. Iraq imposed the ban in response to the U.S.-led multinational military buildup in the region. Saddam said the foreigners' presence would help avert a military confrontation over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Earlier, the official Iraqi News Agency reported that he met with Catholic Archbishop Hilarion Capucci and promised to free ``a large number of Italian nationals.'' There are 270 Italians trapped in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. The agency said Saddam was allowing the Italians to leave in appreciation of Capucci's mission. The report followed the arrival in Baghdad on Saturday of an Alitalia jetliner carrying 25 tons of medical supplies. Capucci was at Baghdad Airport to receive the shipment, the television reported. Capucci is the spiritual head of the 3,000-member Melchite-rite Catholic community of Jerusalem, Arab Christians who have formed an eastern-right branch of the Roman Catholic Church. The Melchite Catholics recognize the primacy of the pope, but have broad independence from the Vatican. The Syrian-born Capucci was jailed for nearly three years by the Israelis on charges of smuggling arms to Palestinian guerrillas. He was released and deported in 1977 after an appeal by Pope Paul VI. He has since been living in Rome. A Finnish delegation arrived in Baghdad Saturday to try to win freedom for Finnish hostages, that nation's radio reported. Two former government ministers, Paavo Vayrynen and Ulf Sundqvist, traveled with Mikko Lohikoski, the vice chairman of the Finnish-Arab Friendship Society. A Finnish Red Cross physician also made the trip to assess the need for emergency aid for Iraqi children.

DOC.HEAD: One U.S. Soldier Killed In Traffic Accident, Another Injured
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army truck and a civilian truck collided early Saturday, killing one American soldier and injuring another, the U.S. military said. The Pentagon said the soldier was the 49th member of the U.S. military to die since Operation Desert Shield began Aug. 7, five days after Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait. Both U.S. soldiers were thrown from the rear of the 2{-ton Army truck in the collision, a military statement said. One was pronounced dead at the scene and the other was taken to a nearby military medical facility for treatment, the statement said. His condition was not disclosed and no other details of the accident were released. The soldiers, who were not identified pending notification of next of kin, were from the 628th Transportation Company, 553rd Combat Support Battalion, 101st Combat Support Group. U.S. military Police and Saudi police are investigating the accident, the statement said. In Washington, Pentagon spokeswoman Jan Walker said the latest fatality was the 46th accidental death since the operation began. She said one soldier also died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound and two people died of natural causes.

DOC.HEAD: Youths Arrested In Connection With School Killings
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Several youths have been arrested in connection with a series of mysterious slayings in Baghdad elementary schools that began after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, diplomatic sources said Saturday. The official media denied there have been any killings, but reported that 22 youths, including two girls, were arrested for ``reckless behavior.'' It was not immediately clear when the arrests were made. The Iraqi news agency carried a statement from the Ministry of the Interior, saying the youths had spread fear in elementary schools. It said they had distributed pamphlets, written on school walls and made telephone calls ``aimed at creating chaos.'' Diplomatic sources reached by telephone said several Baghdad school children had been found slain, their bodies repeatedly slashed, in the toilets of their schools in the Iraqi capital. The diplomats said in one school a slogan written in red said Iraqi children were being killed ``to avenge the killing of the children of Kuwait,'' which Iraq invaded Aug. 2 and annexed six days later. Diplomats said the killings have occurred in the almost four months since Iraq's invasion of the emirate, but gave no specific dates. Later Saturday, state television broadcast confessions from some of the detainees, but none reported committing any action as dramatic as the diplomatic reports. ``Reports of murders are fabricated rumors and lies,'' the television announcer said. The children admitted that they wrote slogans on the walls, sent notes to their classmates frightening them on behalf of a fictitious group that they called ``The Black Hand Gang.'' ``I wrote on the wall of my school, `It is your turn Zaid,' '' said one youth who identified himself as Issam Abdul-Zahra. He did not explain what he meant by that, or provide the full name of the classmate he targetted for what he called ``a joke.'' News reports said Interior Minister Samer Mohammed Abdel Wahab met in an emergency session with Baghdad police Friday to discuss the situation in elementary schools. The minister was quoted as telling police to ``redouble their efforts to encounter those who dare to violate the security and stability of the internal front at a time when Iraq is engaged in battle with the evil enemy.'' His comments and the ministry statement indicated that Iraqi authorities feared some groups within Iraq might be trying to stir domestic unrest while the government focuses on its confrontation over Kuwait with U.S.-led forces.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44, LON2,3,4
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First item embargoed until 7 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The Princess of Wales, Britain's courtly clotheshorse, will have her portrait in the December issue of British Vogue magazine. Buckingham Palace on Sunday released the set of glamor photographs of the princess, wearing off-the-shoulder evening dresses, taken by American photographer Patrick Demarchelier. The result is a formal portrait and two informal studies of Britain's future queen. All the pictures show her with a sophisticated, swept back hairstyle, dark eye makeup and wide smile. In one, she wears a pearl-drop tiara that once belonged to Queen Mary, the Prince of Wales's great-grandmother, and a sedate pearl necklace. The two informal pictures will also be featured in the December issue of the fashion magazine. Demarchelier took pictures of the princess and her sons, Prince William and Prince Harry, last December in the grounds of Highgrove, her Gloucestershire home. --- SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) - The Menudo a go-go is on as the group scrambles to find two replacements for the youthful singers who were fired after being arrested for possessing marijuana. Edgardo Diaz, creator of Menudo and the Puerto Rico-based group's artistic director, said the search for two new Menudos began Friday, after a Miami airport drug-sniffing dog detected small amounts of marijuana in their pants. Oscar Llord, general manager for Sonotone Music, the group's Miami record company, said the group's manager had fired the two singers hours after their arrest. Sergio Gonzalez, 18, and Ruben Gomez, 16, were arrested Thursday at Miami International Airport, Metro-Dade police Lt. James Kaelin said. They have both since been released from custody. ``We've fought hard to keep the group alive, and it's very hard to suffer these setbacks,'' Diaz said. ``These are kids we're very fond of. It breaks my heart. But it does not mean that Menudo is dead.'' Menudo has had several lineups during its years. Members are routinely replaced as they get too old to appeal to their pre-teen and teen audience. --- PIERRE, S.D. (AP) - Kevin Costner, whose directorial debut was an epic tribute to Indian life, has donated $120,000 to create a permanent Sioux Indian exhibit at the South Dakota Cultural Heritage Center. Costner directed and stars in the film ``Dances With Wolves,'' filmed in South Dakota last summer, and now playing nationwide. Costner portrays a cavalry soldier who is befriended by Sioux Indians. Costner and his wife decided to donate the money because they wanted to do something for the state because of the reception they received while making the movie, said Jim Larson, who is doing fund-raising for the cultural center. The exhibit will include a depiction of the rise and fall of the Ghost Dance, the forced retreat of the Sioux, and the transition of the Sioux to reservation life. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Once upon a time, there was a big-mouthed ex-mayor and a former congresswoman who liked hats. The time was Friday, when Ed Koch joined Bella Abzug to read fairy tales to 100 youngsters at the Children's Museum of Manhattan. The former adversaries didn't live happily ever after, but they hooked up for ``Cinderella'' and ``Jack and the Beanstalk.'' The pair read two versions of each tale: a traditional one, and an ``upside-down'' one telling the same story from a different point of view. In the non-traditional ``Cinderella'' read by Abzug, for example, one of the so-called ugly stepsisters ``sets the record straight.'' The stories come from a series of books called ``Upside Down Tales.'' The two made light of their history of political differences. ``I have great respect for her. I happen to like her, even if I disagree with her,'' Koch said before the reading. Abzug echoed Ed: ``If you can't talk with each another, you can't disagree with each other.'' --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Country singer-songwriter Kathy Baillie says uplifting love songs are hard to write because, like love itself, they sometimes end up going bad. ``I like to either write or look for positive love songs because there are so many that are depressing,'' she said recently in an interview. ``They're difficult to write because you start out writing this love song and it becomes, `She left him' and `Now I'm down.' '' She and husband Michael Bonagura are the country duo Baillie and the Boys, whose hit records include ``A Fool Such as I,'' ``Oh, Heart'' and ``Long Shot.'' Bonagura is ``the Boys'' because the group was a trio until member Alan LeBoeuf left a year ago and was not replaced. The two are touring with Kenny Rogers.

DOC.HEAD: Western Military Experts Breaking Trade Embargo on Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western military experts are helping Iraq maintain its production of chemical and other weapons, despite U.N. trade sanctions on that country, Der Spiegel said Saturday. The newsmagazine, which in recent months reported the involvement of German companies in Iraq's military industry, said its information was based on accounts from recently released German hostages and intelligence sources. The sources told Spiegel that Iraqi plants in Samarra were producing 880 pounds daily of Tabun and Lost, two nerve gases. In earlier reports, Spiegel has said that six plants producing poison gas at Samarra, noth of Baghdad, were built by German companies. Dozens of German companies allegedly provided technology and know-how to Iraq, helping the country obtain chemical and other advanced weapons. German companies are also suspected of supplying Iraq with equipment that could be used for making nuclear weapons, according to previous Spiegel reports. Speigel said Saturday that German and other Western experts were helping Iraq keep up production at military sites, including those where Westerners were being held as ``human shields'' to deter attack by multinational forces. Western experts and salesmen are still traveling to Iraq via Jordan to conclude lucrative military contracts, the report said. They have been guaranteed unhindered travel out of Iraq, Spiegel said. Spiegel's report was released to other news media in advance of its publication on Monday. Iraq is known to have a large arsenal of chemical weapons. The U.N. Security Council imposed the trade embargo on Iraq in response to Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. About 350,000 troops from 26 nations have been deployed in the gulf region to try to force Iraq out of Kuwait. In another development, the German Foreign Ministry said it expects most of about 170 Germans still held by Iraq to return to Germany on Sunday. Iraq's president Saddam Hussein has said he was freeing German hostages because the Bonn government is seeking a peaceful solution to the Gulf standoff. German television said 27 employees of the giant Siemens electronics concern were allowed Saturday to leave Iraq and were expected to arrive in Germany during the night on a DC-8 plane chartered by Siemens. The main group of German hostages was expected to arrive in Frankfurt Sunday afternoon aboard an Iraqi Airways plane.

DOC.HEAD: White House, Swiss Officials Trade Charges Over Airport Scuffle
DOC.TEXT: The White House will file a formal protest this week with the Swiss government over a scuffle and shouting match that occurred between members of President Bush's delegation and Swiss security forces at Geneva airport. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater called the security force treatment ``brutal and vicious.'' But Geneva police spokesman Thierry Magnin described the actions of some American reporters as ``deplorable'' and ``inadmissible.'' Fitzwater said a formal protest would be lodged with Swiss Ambassador Edouard Brunner after Bush returns from Mexico. No one was available at the Swiss Embassy in Washington on Saturday to comment. The incidents took place Friday while Bush was en route back to the United States following an eight-day visit to Europe and the Middle East. On Bush's arrival at the airport in Geneva, security officers clashed with newsmen and photographers in the president's party. The press people were pushed and shoved as they sought to approach the ramp on which Bush would leave the plane. Fitzwater said U.S. chief of protocol Joseph Reed was poked in the abdomen with a machine gun, and Jerome Delay, a Washington-based photographer with the French news agency, Agence France-Press, was roughed up. AFP in Washington said Delay was not injured. Swiss foreign ministry spokeswoman Andrea Reichlin said Geneva police were unaware that traveling White House reporters are usually allowed under Air Force One's left wing to watch the president come and go. But reporters traveling with Bush quoted a White House official as saying Swiss police announced without explanation shortly before Bush's arrival that they would bar reporters from that position. ``I've never seen that kind of brutal and vicious treatment by a security force in the last 10 years,'' Fitzwater said. In another incident, Fitzwater said White House chief of staff Jon Sununu was ``verbally attacked'' when he complained about the earlier occurrences. But Magnin, in a telephone interview Saturday, said American reporters ``did not respect security measures taken by Geneva police ... or Swiss territorial sovereignty.'' ``There certainly was a row and heated words, but this was to enforce security measures ... taken in accord with the American security services,'' Magnin said. Magnin said he could not comment on the machine gun incident. ``But if it happened, the submachine gun certainly was not pointed at the diplomat,'' he added. He said Reed may have been mistaken for a non-diplomat because it was dark and he was wearing a trench coat that may have obscured his identifying badge. He said the police were simply doing their job and noted they have long experience with dignitaries coming through Geneva. ``We don't expect to apologize because we think we acted properly to maintain security,'' Magnin said.

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Fired for Making Bomb Threats So He Could Steal Drugs
DOC.TEXT: A veteran sheriff's deputy who told authorities he became addicted to pain killers following surgery has been fired for making bomb threats to pharmacies so he could steal drugs when the stores were evacuated, authorities said. Raymond Leo Novitis was dismissed after admitting telephoning 17 threats in less than a month to feed his addiction, particularly to codeine-based Lortab, Hillsborough County sheriff's Col. Cal Henderson said Saturday. The nine-year veteran was arrested Friday, on duty and in uniform, after he walked out of a drug store where he had responded to a threat he later admitted making, officials said. A stakeout team was waiting outside the Rite Aid Discount Pharmacy, which received two threats two days apart. Novitis was charged with two counts of making bomb threats and remained in jail Saturday on $20,000 ond. Each charge carries a possible 15-year prison sentence. The 40-year-old deputy told detectives he became addicted following an appendectomy in July, after being successfully treated three years ago for a prior addiction. While he recovered from the surgery, he had been assigned to light duty until Oct. 20. The threats to pharmacies in his Brandon patrol area began Oct. 31, Henderson said. ``He was very remorseful. It's a sad situation,'' Henderson said. Detectives had been secretly watching Novitis since last week when they noticed the bomb threats were at stores in his patrol zone, and that Novitis would respond and sign all of the incident reports, Henderson said. Also, one pharmacist told investigators he recognized Novitis' voice from an earlier threat. On Friday, detectives watched Novitis telephone the Rite Aid from a pay phone about a mile away, records show. A tap on the drug store telephone also traced the call to the telephone booth. When the call was dispatched, Novitis volunteered to respond. Detectives closed in after he evacuated the store and was leaving. Novitis also admitted making a bomb threat to the same store Wednesday. Although Novitis has admitted stealing 200-300 prescription pain killers over the past weeks, no drug charges were brought against him because authorities couldn't pinpoint specific thefts. Novitis did not have any drugs with him or in his patrol car when undercover detectives converged on him outside the pharmacy. He said he didn't steal drugs from every store, according to Henderson. Sometimes, the pharmacist wouldn't let him have access to the drug area, and other times there were too many other deputies around. Henderson said none of the pharmacies had noticed or reported any prescription pills missing. Sheriff's investigators will discuss the case with prosecutors next week, Henderson said. Novitis, who has a wife and three children, was treated in 1987 for addiction to the pain killer Percodan, Henderson said. He successfully completed a 28-day treatment program and was randomly tested for drugs. But no tests had been done since he returned to work in October, Henderson said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Unveils Draft Union Treaty But Six Republics Won't Sign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th pvs, `It is...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Lithuanian president's comments. Pickup 8th pvs, `Instead, many...' ^By ANDREW KATELL
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday offered the 15 Soviet republics a treaty giving them control over virtually all affairs except defense. But his draft was dead on arrival in nearly half the republics. The long-awaited draft union treaty, published in major newspapers, is Gorbachev's attempt to stop the rapid splintering of political unity in this huge and diverse country of 285 million people. It is his blueprint for saving a degree of central authority. It addresses some of the issues behind bloody ethnic conflicts and a ``paralysis of power'' hindering economic reform and worsening shortages of food and consumer goods. The proposed treaty, drafted by Gorbachev and other members of the Federation Council, would rename the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics the ``Union of Sovereign Soviet Republics.'' The treaty said the union would be ``voluntary'' but did not identify who in each republic - voters or legislators - would decide whether to join. Each republic, ``as a sovereign state, has full state powers over its territory. Treaty participants regard the Soviet Union as a sovereign federative state formed as a result of the republics' voluntary union,'' the draft says. The blueprint was sent to the legislatures of the union and the 15 republics for approval. It is there that more trouble lies ahead for Gorbachev, whose influence and power over the country is eroding. ``Not only the Baltic states, but also many Soviet republics, will not sign this treaty,'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said in a television address to his republic, which is in the forefront of drives to break from Moscow. At least six republics have already indicated they will not sign: Armenia, Ukraine Georgia, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. The participation of other republics is in doubt because of drives for sovereignty or independence that have swept all but one - Kirgizia. Instead, many republics have been bypassing the Kremlin and signing treaties with each other governing trade, cultural and political ties. According to the draft union treaty, the Kremlin would continue to control defense and borders. It would administer jointly with republics an economic development program, the space program, transportation and the energy system. The treaty rebuffs plans by several republics to introduce their own currencies to replace the Soviet ruble, whose value has plummeted. The draft says the union will join the republics in setting monetary policy ``based on a single currency.'' The draft also says the republics will own land and natural resources, except for those the union needs to exercise its powers. Many republics claim the central government has taken their land and resources and used them for wasteful and polluting factories. The treaty would leave virtually all other issues - such as management of the economy, education and culture - to the republics. In the current system, central ministries in Moscow supervise factories nationwide, often in disregard for local conditions. The draft presents a formula for resolving jurisdictional disputes that have paralyzed and confused the country for weeks, especially holding up the transition from a centrally planned to a market economy. In declarations of sovereignty, most republics and many regions within them have declared local laws supreme over national legislation. The draft union treaty proclaims, ``the supremacy of republic legislation over republics' territories on all questions, except those which are referred to the jurisdiction of the union.'' The treaty, which would replace a 1922 accord that united the 15 republics but gave them few powers, says nothing about how a republic might secede. The national legislature passed a law in April that requires two-thirds of a republic's voters to approve secession in a referendum. The republic would have to wait up to five years while the terms of secession are negotiated. Gorbachev has maintained the people in the republics want to remain in the union, and criticized republic legislators for ``separatism.'' At a news conference Friday, Gorbachev warned that any attempt to break up the Soviet Union without calling a referendum could lead to ``bloodshed and civil conflict.''

DOC.HEAD: Man's Attempt at Sailing Record Swamped by 50-foot Wave
DOC.TEXT: Two sailors, one from this western Michigan city, were defeated by mountainous waves off the tip of South America in their quest to break a 136-year-old sailing record, a spokeswoman said. Steve Pettengill, 39, of Grand Rapids and Rick Wilson, 40, of Boston left San Francisco on Oct. 22 in Wilson's 60-foot triamaran Great American. They were attempting to reach Boston in less than 76 days and six hours - the record set in 1853 by the cargo-laden clipper Northern Light. But 50-foot waves driven by winds up to 80 mph overturned the Great American off Cape Horn about 10 a.m. Thanksgiving Day, said Barbara Kalunian, who spoke to Wilson via a ship-to-shore radio Friday. Wilson said a larger wave righted the craft about an hour later. The mast was broken into three pieces. Wilson and Pettengill had been in the water 31 days and were about four days ahead of the record Wednesday. The sailors, pelted by hail and freezing rain, huddled in the swamped craft for 14 hours. They were rescued Thursday night by the 900-foot container ship New Zealand Pacific. The huge ship nearly plowed over the helpless craft before crew members spotted flares shot off by Wilson and Pettengill. ``At the end, I really couldn't even open my eyes (to look at the waves) - it was that frightening,'' Wilson told Kalunian. ``Obviously the forces of the sea are very strong.'' The voyage was intended in part to raise funds for the American Lung Association, which had a 900 telephone number set up where interested people could call - for a fee - and hear progress reports on the trip. Wilson said both men were in good condition. The New Zealand Pacific was bound for the Netherlands, where it was scheduled to arrive Dec. 10. The men will go on to the Netherlands before making the journey back to the U.S. The sailors knew foul weather and treacherous seas probably would greet them off Cape Horn, where the Atlantic and Pacific oceans collide. After the boat was overturned, the men activated a satellite-relayed distress signal designed to alert U.S. Coast Guard and Chilean officials. A rescue plane had spotted the freighter about 100 miles from the Great American. The crew dropped lines overboard, which Wilson and Pettengill tied around their waists. In a dangerous rescue mission in darkness and 30-35-foot waves, Wilson and Pettengill jumped to a rope ladder dangling from the New Zealand Pacific. In 1989, Pettengill and a Canadian sailor successfully rounded Cape Horn from east to west to break by 12 days a 135-year-old record set by the clipper Flying Cloud.

DOC.HEAD: Six Teens Charged in Theft of Sports Trading Cards
DOC.TEXT: Six teen-agers have been arrested in the theft of $50,000 worth of sports trading cards, only about half of which were recovered, police said. A 15-year-old, two 16-year-olds and two 17-year-olds were each charged with two counts of burglary and two counts of grand larceny, police said Friday. Larry Bolin, 18, of Virginia Beach, faced those counts as well as conspiracy to commit burglary, police said. The arrests took place over several days early last week, police said. The theft occurred Oct. 21 at a storage shed used by trading card dealer Bill Mittlestadt, part owner of A.H. Coins & Stamps. The thieves took the hottest items, Mittlestadt said. ``They were versed enough to only take the most in-demand merchandise,'' he said. None of the missing cards is individually worth more than $500, but the stolen sets included a 1990 Star Pick premier basketball edition of 70 cards, featuring David Robinson and Danny Ferry. Also stolen were several cases of Upper Deck baseball cards featuring Ken Griffey Jr. and Bo Jackson. Some of the arrested youths are collectors who have been in his business, Mittlestadt said. ``I knew some of the kids involved,'' he said. ``We give the kids all the breaks we can. It really hurt.''

DOC.HEAD: Polls Indicate Conservatives - Without Thatcher - Moving Ahead of Labor
With AM-The Thatcher Years, Bjt
By SUE LEEMAN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Party heavyweights lined up behind the three candidates in the party leadership contest Saturday, and polls showed the Conservatives moving ahead of Labor with a new leader at the helm. Former defense secretary Michael Heseltine, Chancellor John Major and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd are spending the weekend canvassing the 372 Tory lawmakers who will choose between them in Tuesday's second round of voting. Each man claims he is the best candidate to rally a party torn by in-fighting and further shaken by the decision to resign Thursday of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Tory leader for 15 years and prime minister for 11{. The Sunday Express newspaper reported 116 of the 334 Tory lawmakers it contacted said they would vote for Major, 49 for Heseltine and 34 for Hurd. Eighty-one had no comment and 54 said they did not know, the newspaper said. Heseltine's challenge to Mrs. Thatcher in round one of the ballot on Tuesday precipitated her departure. His campaign got a boost Saturday with declared support from former Chancellor Nigel Lawson and former deputy prime minister Sir Geoffrey Howe. Heseltine said later his chances of winning ``are getting better by the phone call.'' Howe resigned Nov. 1 in protest at Mrs. Thatcher's rejection of a plan adopted by the 11 other European Community leaders to set up a single central bank by 1994 and a single currency. Lawson resigned in the middle of last year after a dispute rooted in the same monetary issues. Major said 50 Tory lawmakers were working in his campaign team, ``and the reports we are getting from the constitutuencies are very encouraging.'' He picked up support Saturday from Social Security Secretary Tony Newton and Transport Minister Roger Freeman. Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Brooke declared his support for Hurd. Hurd said he was even with Heseltine and added ``there will certainly be a third ballot.'' Heseltine won 152 votes in the first round against Mrs. Thatcher's 204, with 16 abstentions. If none of the three candidates receives a majority Tuesday, a third ballot will be held Thursday. Opinion polls out Saturday showed Heseltine and Major were likely to beat Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock if a general election were held now. The Conservatives' chances of victory were less under Hurd. The Conservatives trailed Labor, the main opposition party in Parliament, for the last 16 months in opinion polls. An ICM poll for the Sunday Correspondent newspaper found that 47 percent of people would vote for Heseltine, compared with 38 percent who would vote Labor, according to the poll of 1,139 people taken on Friday. Major received 46 percent of the vote, compared with 39 percent for Labor and Hurd had 43 percent of the vote, compared with Labor's 41 percent, the poll showed. A Market and Opinions Research International poll of 1,094 voters for the Sunday Times gave the Tories a six-point lead over Labor with either Heseltine or Major as prime minister. Under Hurd the Conservative margin would narrow to 2 percent, the poll found. A Gallup poll put the Tories under Heseltine at 47 percent against Labor's 39 percent while the party under Major would command 42.5 percent against Labor's 40 percent. Under Hurd the Conservatives would be at 40.5 percent with Labor at 42 percent, according to the poll of 1,063 people taken Friday for the Sunday Telegraph. An NMR poll for the Independent on Sunday newspaper found the Tories under Major would be on 48 percent to Labor's 40 percent while under Heseltine the Conservatives would lead Labor 47 percent to 42 percent. Under Hurd the two major parties would be even. No margin of error was given.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Red Army in Germany Says 84 Soldiers Have Deserted
DOC.TEXT: The commander of the Soviet army in Germany said 84 soldiers had deserted in recent months, but he denied news reports that black market dealing and mysterious deaths were rampant among the troops. It was the first time the Soviets have provided figures on the number of deserters. Gen. Boris Vasilievich Snetkov said 36 soldiers had left the army and turned themselves in to German authorities. The other 48 were missing, he said. The 380,000 troops stationed in eastern Germany are the largest contingent of the Red Army outside the Soviet Union. They are to be withdrawn by 1994. Snetkov told a news conference that they face a ``relatively tense'' situation in the planned pullout from Germany over the next four years. But he denied reports that the contingent was falling apart, plagued by low morale, internal fighting and mysterious deaths. Recently, German and Soviet officials have expressed concern about the Soviet troops still stationed in Germany. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev spoke of an ``anti-Soviet flavor'' during his meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Bonn earlier this month. The troops have become a bitter remnant of the Cold War occupation, and many Germans are anxious to see them leave. The soldiers, however, face an uncertain future at home, no guarantee of housing and the loss of access to Western affluence and material goods. Germany has promised $8 billion to the Soviet Union to help finance the withdrawal. In an interview published Saturday in the eastern German daily Junge Welt, a Soviet lawyer and human rights activist was quoted as saying there were 800 deaths among Soviet troops in 1988 and that he was investigating more than 2,000 deaths in ``mysterious circumstances.'' Oleg Liamin also was quoted as saying Soviet barracks operate under a ``regime of terror'' where extortion and beatings among the troops are common. Other reports in the German press have said that Red Army soldiers, desperate for German marks, allegedly raid depots and trade weapons and uniforms on the black market. Soviet privates are paid only $16 a month. Snetkov called the reports of black market trade ``a lie'' and said the reported number of alleged deaths among the troops in eastern Germany was ``ten times too high.'' The actual number is about 100 a year, he said. ``We know our stay in this country brings inconveniences to the people,'' he said. ``But the people must understand that the forces must fulfill their training duties as army of the Soviet Union.'' He said anti-Soviet sentiment by some Germans was only making the pullout more difficult. He said many Soviet soldiers have been robbed by Germans. Closer contact between the Red Army and the Bundeswehr, Germany's armed force, will ease tensions in the coming period, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Kills More Than 50 Horses in Stable Fire
DOC.TEXT: An early morning fire turned a commercial stables into a ruin, killing more than 50 show and race horses here Saturday. The fire broke out at about 4 a.m., apparently in one of two wings that housed the horses. Fire officials said the cause of the blaze was still under investigation, and said they had not ruled out arson. Scott Laffey, who leased the Sabbath Day Farm and ran the stables, said he dashed to the barn from his nearby home when he heard a signal from an alarm. He blindfolded two horses and shooed them out of the barn, but only four horses survived. ``A horse will run back into the stall,'' Laffey said. ``That's the problem.'' The intense heat razed one wing of the red barn, and destroyed much of the second wing. ``The whole sky over there was just red,'' said Kathy Clemenzi, a neighbor who could see the fire from her home. ``It just lit up the sky.'' ``It would be like an oven,'' said Police Chief Roger Merry. The charred carcasses of horses lay in rows where their stalls had been. Fire officials and the farm's owner, Marshall Jespersen, spent the morning photographing and identifying the remains. Laffey said he was not sure exactly how many horses died, but estimated about 55 were killed. The horses were worth between $5,000 and $35,000 apiece, Laffey said. Merry estimated the total loss was worth more than $2 million. Firefighters had to bring in water tankers and pump water from a nearby pond to douse the flames. Laffey said the fire accelerated quickly, leading him to wonder whether it may have been set. No hay was stored in the barn. ``In my heart, I believe it took off too fast,'' he said. Merry said investigators ``have not drawn conclusions one way or another'' on whether arson was involved. Horse owners who had lodged and trained their animals at the farm came to survey the damage. Matthew Morton said his brother and sister-in-law, a New Hampshire couple who were housing three horses while they were on a trip, were heartbroken. ``They'd just absolutely fallen in love with those horses,'' Morton said. Said Kathy Borylo, who trained horses at the farm: ``My customers are all devastated.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Whaling Fleet Leaves for Antarctic
DOC.TEXT: Defying international appeals, Japan launched the fourth season of its controversial research whaling program Saturday with plans to kill up to 330 whales. Environmentalists charge the program is a cover for continued commercial whaling. The mother ship Nisshin Maru No. 3 left Saturday for the Antarctic Ocean, where it is to be joined by three smaller boats for four months of whaling, Kyodo News Service reported. They officially plan to catch 300 minke whales, a relatively abundant smaller species. The research program allows up to 330 animals to be killed. In July, Japan, Norway and Iceland appealed unsuccessfully at a meeting of the International Whaling Commission for minkes to be excluded from the commission's moratorium on commercial whaling. Nobuyuki Yagi, a Fishery Agency official, said Japan hopes information about minke populations gathered by the fleet this season will encourage the commission to re-evaluate the moratorium, instituted in 1986 after many of the great whale species were hunted close to extinction. Japanese officials say whales must be killed during the research to accurately determine their age, sex, childbearing state, diet and health. Environmentalists say non-lethal research methods are available, such as skin samplings and sighting studies. Japan officially stopped its commercial whaling at the end of the 1986-87 season, when it caught 1,941 whales. It then began a program of research whaling, which is permitted under the whaling commission's charter. Japanese whalers killed 273 animals in the first year of the research program, 241 in the second and 330 in the third. At its meeting this year, the commission passed non-binding resolutions questioning whether Japan's research program was scientifically accurate and urging it to use non-lethal methods wherever possible, officials said. Although Japanese whaling officials previously said at least 825 whales must be caught each year to make the program scientifically valid, Japanese experts recalculated the sampling error in response to the IWC resolutions and determined that 300 was sufficient, Yagi said. Japan also appealed at the IWC meeting for permission to hunt 50 minke whales commercially each year along its coast, saying small traditional whaling communities had been damaged by the moratorium, Yagi said. But that proposal also was rejected. The minke reaches about 30 feet in length and eight tons in weight, and is the smallest of the commercially sought great whales. The commission estimates there are about 760,000 minkes in the Antarctic and about 83,000 in the North Atlantic. Officials say whaling also is an important part of the Japanese diet and culture. Japan is the world's largest consumer of whale meat, and whales provided 23 percent of the nation's meat when Japanese whaling was at its peak in the early 1960s. Whale meat is now considered a delicacy because of its limited supply.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Militia Begins Pullout From Beirut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs to ADD dropped word ``was''
DOC.TEXT: The main Christian militia started withdrawing its heavy weapons from east Beirut on Saturday, removing the last major obstacle to President Elias Hrawi's demilitarization of the capital. The move by the Lebanese Forces militia was ``the first phase in a 48-hour total withdrawal from east Beirut,'' a spokesman for the militia said. The pullout began five days after a Nov. 19 deadline set by Hrawi in his effort to create a militia-free zone in the so-called ``Greater Beirut'' area. The pullot is the first phase of an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's 15{-year-old civil war. Private militias have been blamed for most of the estimated 150,000 deaths during the fighting, and their forces had siphoned off taxes from a weakened and divided central government. The major Moslem militias withdrew before the deadline. But the Lebanese Forces, led by Samir Geagea, refused to leave until rival pro-Syrian Christians and other Syrian-backed forces returned Lebanese Forces offices they had seized. Geagea also demanded guarantees that the pro-Syrian forces would not be allowed into east Beirut after the Lebanese Forces withdrew. The pro-Syrian Christian forces are led by Geagea's bitter rival, Elie Hobeika. A Geagea spokesman, who declined to be identified, said the Lebanese Forces demands had been met, with the government ordering the anti-Hobeika Fifth Brigade of the army to police most of east Beirut. Militiamen of the 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces loaded mortars, machine guns, recoilless cannons and cases of ammunition onto 30 trucks near their headquarters in the seaside district of Karantina. The convoy headed north along the coastal boulevard to Kesrouan province, which lies outside the ``Greater Beirut'' area. The spokesman said the militia will evacuate some 400 fighters, 40 tanks and 50 armored personnel carriers from Beirut's Christian sector. Government troops will move into metropolitan Beirut's Karantina, Nabaa and Ashrafiyeh districts, traditional Lebanese Forces strongholds, ``as our pullout proceeds,'' the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. When the operation was completed Monday, these districts ``will be in the hands of the Lebanese army,'' he said. The Greater Beirut zone will cover a 15-mile coastal stretch from the Dog River in the north to the Damour River in the south and extend east and northeast to encompass part of the Christian heartland that had been controlled by rebel Gen. Michel Aoun. Aoun had defied Hrawi for 11 months until the president's Syrian allies crushed his mutiny last month. Hrawi hopes to disband the militias and extend long-absent state authority over all of Lebanon. But disarming the militias who have long held sway will be a formidable task. Another complication is Israel's occupation of a border strip in southern Lebanon. Israel has made clear it will not pull out of its self-declared ``security zone'' while anti-Israeli armed factions roam freely in southern Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Tattoo Parlors Shot in Arm For Town's Economy
DOC.TEXT: A pair of dueling tattoo parlors is giving this rural Maine town's local business scene a shot in the arm. Both businesses began within the last two months, and despite the region's sluggish economy, both report a booming demand for body art. ``Customers are coming out of the woodwork now,'' said 43-year-old Roy Whitney, who opened Whitney's Creative Tattoos in an old key shop. Part of the reason business is brisk may be the fact that tattooing is illegal in New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts, he said. Richie Slamm, 53, who operates Mithras Tattoos, boasts 97 tattoos of his own. Slamm learned his trade at New York's Coney Island during the 1950s when the process was still legal, doing his first tattoo when he was 12. Whitney, a former construction worker, got into the business three years ago after he was injured on his old job. Though they're business rivals, Whitney, who wears 20 tattoos, and Slamm have artistic respect for each other. Slamm is working on a jungle scene that will eventually cover Whitney's back. It features a panther leaping through the flesh into a forest of tangled vines and waiting predators. Both men plan to hire assistants so they can keep up with people's demand for colorful unicorns, dragons, daggers and rainbows to adorn their bodies. As an added draw, they are offering holiday gift certificates.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Government Protesters Scuffle With Government Supporters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7 pvs, `Despite surviving ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with government statement on strike, poll showing declining Lukanov support. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `Opponents seeking ...'
DOC.TEXT: About 30,000 demonstrators rallied to back embattled Premier Andrei Lukanov on Saturday, one day after he narrowly survived a no-confidence vote. Government opponents blocked a main boulevard in protest. Some fights broke out between government supporters and opponents but hundreds of police intervened to prevent serious clashes. Lukanov told the crowd Saturday that he was ``no coward'' and accused the opposition of trying ``to establish a new political monopoly.'' Lukanov is among a group of former Communists who toppled longtime ruler Todor Zhivkov last year and oversaw parliamentary elections. The no-confidence vote Friday followed months of wrangling between the former Communists and the opposition on how to turn around the moribund economy and end the country's political paralysis. The government's failure to stop the economic decline and improve supplies of scarce foods and consumer goods has led to growing demands for Lukanov's resignation from frustrated citizens. An official survey broadcast on television Saturday said Lukanov had a 50 percent approval rating. Last month, 71 percent supported him. Despite surviving the confidence vote, Lukanov's government faces more pressure by the main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, which has called for a mass demonstration in Sofia on Sunday. The opposition trade union confederation Podkrepa has called a general strike for Monday if Lukanov does not resign by then, despite a warning by the prosecutor general that political strikes are not permitted. The government issued a statement Saturday on television demanding the strike be called off, saying it would ``endanger our parliamentary system ... intensify the political instability, and have an extremely detrimental effect on the international prestige of our young democracy.'' The main trade union confederation announced it would not support the strike. Opponents seeking Lukanov's resignation demonstrated in Sofia every day last week. But on Saturday, government supporters gathered outside the fire-damaged headquarters of the Socialist Party to cheer Lukanov, who declared he would not resign under pressure. The building, which housed the former Communist Party before it became the Socialist Party early this year, was set afire by anti-Communist demonstrators in August. About 2,000 opposition supporters gathered within sight of the Socialist-sponsored rally, chanting slogans against Lukanov and his party. A thick line of police equipped with riot gear separated the two demonstrations but some scuffles erupted when the pro-government rally began to disperse. Several hundred opposition supporters blocked the capital's main boulevard by sitting or lying in the road to block the way of pro-government demonstrators. Helmeted police with nightsticks called on the protesters to clear the street, but refrained from using force to disperse them. After about an hour the police withdrew and the protesters dispersed peacefully. Opposition leaders claim they would triumph in new elections. They have repeatedly rejected Lukanov's requests to join a broad Socialist-led coalition government, insisting instead on naming the premier and holding key ministries. The Socialist Party won free elections in June and holds 210 seats in Parliament. The opposition Union has 144 seats. Lukanov repeated he was open to dialogue with the opposition and reiterated his determination to push through badly needed reforms to turn around the failing economy. However, he warned that he could not promise ``easy days'' under the tough reforms. ``The program will be difficult, even cruel.''

DOC.HEAD: Thearapists Cancel 1992 Minneapolis Convention To Protest Abortion Law
DOC.TEXT: The American Family Therapy Association has canceled plans to hold its 1992 convention in Minneapolis to protest a state law requiring teen-age girls to notify their parents before having an abortion. The group objects to the 1981 law which also mandates that minors seek a judge's permission if they want to avoid notifying their parents. The U.S. Supreme Court upheld the law in June. The cancellation means a loss of nearly $180,000 to the local economy, according to Peter Hedlund, vice president of the Greater Minneapolis Convention and Visitors Association. That figure is based on attendance of 300 conventioneers. Marilyn Mason, a Minneapolis psychologist and a member of the American Family Therapy Association board, said Friday that the board decided by a ``100 percent consensus'' to boycott Minneapolis when it learned of the Minnesota law during a Massachusetts retreat in September. ``Since our organization opposes government interference in the reproductive decisions of Americans, especially those that deny poor Americans their right to privacy, we cannot, in good conscience, have our convention in Minnesota,'' Mason wrote in a letter to the editor of the Star Tribune. Rachael Hare-Muftin, the association's president, told Minneapolis Mayor Don Fraser and St. Paul Mayor Jim Scheibel of the cancellation in separate letters. ``My impression is that the law we have doesn't work very well, but it's the Legislature that's got the responsibility,'' Fraser said. Greg Ortale, president of the convention and visitors association, said: ``If that's the way they feel, they should go with their beliefs.'' The law was in effect five years before a challenge by several abortion clinics led U.S. District Judge Donald Alsop to declare it unconstitutional in 1986. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals later ruled that the law was valid but blocked its enforcement pending a U.S. Supreme Court review. In June, the nation's high court ruled that states do not impose an ``undue burden'' on pregnant girls by requiring them to notify parents or receive court permission if they don't want to tell their parents. After the Supreme Court's ruling, the Minnesota law was reinstated Aug. 27.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Gunboat Sinks Dinghy, Kills Five Guerrillas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs with background on pvs attacks; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli gunboat sank a dinghy off the Lebanese coast Saturday, killing five armed guerrillas who were apparently en route to attack an Israeli target, according to radio reports and military sources. It was not immediately known if there were any survivors from the dinghy, Israeli radio reported. It said there were no Israeli casualties. The Israeli military had no official statement on the incident late Saturday, but military sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, confirmed the sinking and said it was under investigation. Reports on Israel radio and broadcasts in Beirut said the guerrillas were planning an attack in Israel. The Moslem Voice of the Nation and the Christian Voice of Lebanon said the dinghy sank off Saadiyat, about 12 miles south of Beirut. They did not identify the guerrillas killed or provide any other details. The reported clash came four days after Israeli troops and allied militiamen of the South Lebanon Army ambushed a Palestinian guerrilla squad in southeast Lebanon. Police and the Israeli command said four guerrillas and an Israeli officer were killed in the eight-hour firefight near the village of Ain Atta, in the foothills of Mount Hermon. The Libyan-backed Palestine Popular Struggle Front, a small radical group of Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization, identified the guerrillas in that battle as members of its force. An abortive attack on an Israeli beach by seaborne guerrillas in May prompted the United States to cut off its 18-month dialogue with the PLO. That attempt was claimed by an Iraqi-backed group, the Palestine Liberation Front.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican State Elections Test Electoral Fairness
DOC.TEXT: Elections planned in Yucatan state on Sunday have been promoted as a showcase of the government's new tolerance of rival parties, even as it fights widespread allegations of fraud in other regions. The voting comes on the eve of a visit by President Bush to the northern city of Monterrey to discuss a free trade pact, part of the economic and political opening announced by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. About 650,000 voters are registered to cast ballots for 106 mayoral posts and 25 state deputies in Yucatan. Six parties are competing in the rural southeastern state, famous for the Mayan ruins of Chichen Itza and others, but polls indicate the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has strong support across the state. ``In Yucatan, there are all the conditions to have clean and democratic elections,'' Gov. Victor Manzanilla Schaeffer was quoted as saying by the government news agency Notimex last week. He said those who failed to understand that the Mexican election system had changed ``will be exposed publicly.'' Salinas took office in December 1988 and has promised to clean up Mexican elections. In 1989, the government recognized an opposition party victory in a gubernatorial race for the first time in decades. But opposition figures claim the government has repeatedly resorted to fraud in other state elections by organizing caravans of illegal voters, ballot box theft and inaccurate voter rolls. In Yucatan, polls by the private surveying agencies Opina and Con-Ciencia indicated a strong PRI lead throughout the state. Con-Ciencia noted, however, that 47 percent of the registered voters surveyed refused to give an opinion. The PRI, in power for more than 60 years, is far more organized than the opposition and has more rewards to give backers in the form of jobs, favors and government spending. It is also the only party running in all 106 municipalities, including 32 where it is unopposed. The leftist Mexico City daily La Jornada reported that opposition parties saw little chance to win more than 20 of the mayoral races. Members of the conservative National Action Party and the leftist Democratic Revolution Party told the state election commission Friday there were signs of impending vote fraud. They charged the government has issued two conflicting lists of polling locations and districts which could allow people to vote twice. They also complained that the PRI-dominated electoral commission rejected 60 poll watchers from the National Action Party and 45 observers from the Democratic Revolution Party. The daily El Universal said the opposition proposed having electoral commission members sign individual ballots at the close of voting to prevent additions of forged ballots later. National Action and Democratic Revolution parties have boycotted meetings of the federal Electoral College, which is certifying results of the Nov. 11 elections in Mexico and Hidalgo states, to protest alleged fraud. Preliminary official results gave the PRI 116 of 121 mayoral contests in Mexico state, where it lost in 1988 presidential voting. They also gave the PRI 81 of 84 mayoral spots in the east-central state of Hidalgo.

DOC.HEAD: Protest Over Airline Fare Increase Blocks Plane
DOC.TEXT: Easter Islanders protesting a doubling of the air fare to the mainland stormed the island's only landing strip, blocking a flight carrying 200 tourists, authorities said Saturday. The Chilean carrier LAN canceled the flight to Tahiti until at least Monday, when airline officials are scheduled to discuss the fare hike with the governor of the South Pacific island. LAN, the only airline operating to the island, increased the round-trip fare from the island to the Chilean mainland from $206 to $410. The island with a population of 2,000, annexed by Chile in 1888, is about 2,300 miles west of Santiago. It is famous for giant stone carvings of heads and hieroglyphs, whose origins are the subject of debate. The protest began Friday when a group of mostly young islanders blocked the jet as it prepared to take off. Some of the protesters remained on the landing strip Saturday, police said. Several had parked trucks and cars to prevent the airplane from taking off. Island officials pleaded with the protesters to clear the strip. Airline officials said they agreed to a meeting Monday with the island's governor, Jacobo Hei, and said the fare increase may be reversed. But Interior Minister Enrique Krauss said the government will not subsidize the fare, ``because residents in other remote areas would certainly ask for a similar treatment, and we can not do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Worldwide Call For Peace in Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto LON12
DOC.TEXT: Peace activists took to the streets of several European and North American cities Saturday to demand that Western nations pull their military forces from the Persian Gulf. Protesters marched through central London and held a demonstration in Hyde Park. Police estimated the crowd at about 5,000. But the organizers, the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, said it was three times that. The marchers carried placards saying ``Out of the Gulf'' and chanted anti-war slogans. British officials announced Thursday that Britain would send 14,000 more men to the gulf after Christmas. There now are 16,000 British troops in the region as part of a multinational force deployed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. At Saturday's protest in London, Labor Party lawmaker and veteran peace campaigner Tony Benn told the crowd that opposition to a military option in the gulf was growing. ``World opposition to the gulf war is growing so rapidly that humanity has the best chance ever of forcing a superpower to accept a peaceful solution. That is why our campaign is so important now,'' he said. Benn was to leave Sunday for Baghdad. He said he would try to negotiate a peaceful solution to the crisis and the release of foreign hostages held by Iraq. In a separate protest in Bonn, about 6,000 people carrying banners saying ``No Blood for Oil'' rallied. The demonstration was organized by the Greens party and other leftist groups. Police seized leaflets passed out by Greens officials urging German soldiers to desert in case they were sent to the gulf. German officials say the country's constitution prevents the government from sending troops outside NATO areas, and there are no German soldiers with the international force in Saudi Arabia. But Chancellor Helmut Kohl has said he will seek a constitutional amendment that will allow Germany to participate in military actions sponsored by the United Nations. Other leaflets distributed at the rally condemned ``the brutal regime'' of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, his aggression against Kuwait and the taking of foreign hostages. But the leaflets said this was not reason enough to plunge the gulf region into a war that would cause massive loss of life. In Toronto, about 200 people rallied outside the U.S. Consulate and then marched to city hall Saturday to protest the Western military buildup in the gulf. Chanting ``Hell, no, we won't go; we won't die for Texaco!'' the group marched in a light snowfall and made their way down University Avenue with a police escort. The protesters were part of a loose coalition of several groups that oppose the U.S. and Canadian military presence in the gulf. They called for an immediate withdrawal of all foreign troops in the region. In Ottawa, about 200 peace activists gathered at the National War Memorial on Parliament Hill to protest Canada's involvement in the gulf. About 1,500 Canadian troops are in the region. The United States has about 230,000 soldiers there. In Newark, N.J, a small group of activists protested against the presence of U.S. troops in the gulf, saying poor blacks are unfairly sent abroad to fight a rich man's war for oil. Lawrence Hamm, chairman of the New Jersey Rainbow Coalition, said a disproportionately large number of black solders were sent to the Middle East to take part in the multinational force. The 16 protestors plan to repeat the demonstration monthly until the soldiers come home, Hamm said.

DOC.HEAD: Beeper Saves Man from Bullet During Struggle with Assailant
DOC.TEXT: A beeper at his waist saved a man from a bullet fired while he fought a masked gunman in an underground garage, police said. Three more shots went off during the struggle Friday and the last one hit the gunman, killing him. The dead man was identified as Vernon Justice, 23, of Inglewood, Detective Bill Collette said. The names of the 19-year-old woman and 25-year-old man who were accosted were withheld. Justice died at Long Beach Memorial Hospital shortly after being shot once in the chest at 9 p.m. Wearing a ski mask and rubber gloves, the gunman grabbed the woman in the garage beneath an apartment building, Collette said. ``He put an arm around her throat, covered her mouth with his hand and put a gun to her head, and asked, `Which car is yours?''' said Detective Logan Wrenn. The boyfriend then entered the garage and the gunman let go of the woman, Collette said. The boyfriend grabbed for the gun. It went off but the shot was deflected by the beeper, Collette said. One shot hit the garage floor and a second punctured a car tire. The third hit Justice. The district attorney's office will review the police reports, Collette said, adding he believed the boyfriend acted ``in self-defense and in defense of his girlfriend.''

DOC.HEAD: Ground Computer Problem That Interrupted Venus Mapping Is Fixed
DOC.TEXT: Engineers corrected a ground control computer error which halted the Magellan spacecraft's mapping of Venus, NASA officials said Saturday. ``Everything is fine,'' said Bob MacMillan, spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The problem was corrected about 8 a.m. Saturday, 2{ hours before the start of the next mapping cycle. ``It was a rather minor disconnect last night because of some command errors transmitted from the ground. The spacecraft didn't recognize a series of commands and decided to put itself in a safe position,'' MacMillan said. ``It did not break communications the way it did in August, it just reduced its information rate. It sent back slow signals, but no mapping data.'' The spacecraft, which circles Venus every three hours and 15 minutes, ``lost about three orbits,'' after it stopped mapping about 8 p.m. Friday, he said. It was the second report of problems with Magellan's mapping mission in eight days. The Magellan signal was lost for 40 minutes Nov. 15. Signals were lost twice in August. Engineers have lost contact with Magellan three times for reasons not yet fully understood, but believed to be electric static interfering with a spacecraft computer. Magellan was launched from the space shuttle Atlantis on May, 4, 1989. It went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 and formally started its $744 million mapping mission Sept. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Hint at Improved Ties Between Britain and Syria
DOC.TEXT: Britain and Syria may soon restore diplomatic relations, the official news agency in Damascus reported Saturday. Ties were cut four years ago over Syria's alleged support of terrorists. The thaw may also raise hopes for the release of some of the 13 Westerners held by pro-Iranian Moslem extremists in Lebanon, where Syria has about 40,000 troops. An editorial in the Syrian government newspaper Tishrin earlier this month linked the release of hostages with restoration of Anglo-Syrian relations. The official Syrian Arab News Agency said Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa conferred Saturday with David Gore-Booth, a British Foreign Office official. The Foreign Office in London confirmed that Gore-Booth, undersecretary responsible for relations with the Middle East, was ``discussing bilateral problems that prevent the resumption of diplomatic ties.'' The meeting was held shortly after the Syrian minister returned home with President Hafez Assad from Geneva, where Assad and President Bush discussed the Persian Gulf crisis Friday. The Tishrin newspaper, which normally reflects government thinking, held Britain's outgoing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher responsible for blocking improved ties. Mrs. Thatcher announced her resignation last week. It was the first public contact between British and Syrian government officials since November 1986, when London severed relations after accusing Syria of masterminding an attempt to blow up an Israeli jetliner at Heathrow Airport outside London seven months earlier. In December 1988, a Damascus-based radical group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, was implicated in an explosion aboard a Pan Am jumbo jet over Lockerbie, Scotland. However, no one has been prosecuted for the attack, which killed 270 people. Later reports from U.S. intelligence and other sources blamed Libyan and Iranian terrorists for the Pan Am bombing. The Tishrin newspaper had criticized Mrs. Thatcher for taking no steps toward improving ties after Syria sided with the Western alliance against Iraq following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It also attacked Britain for allegedly pressuring its 11 partners in the European Community to maintain sanctions against Syria, which deprived Damascus of an annual $192 million development loan and restricted the number of Syrian diplomats allowed to work in EC capitals. The U.S. State Department still lists Syria as one of the main Middle East countries that sponsor terrorism and violate human rights. However, U.S. officials had publicly thanked Syria for helping secure the release of American hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed in Lebanon last April. Ireland said Syria helped free Brian Keenan, an Irish citizen, in August. The 13 remaining hostages include six Americans, four Britons, two Germans and an Italian. The longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon is Associated Press chief Middle East correspondent Terry Anderson, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Body of Flight Instructor Recovered From Helicopter Crash
DOC.TEXT: Army divers on Saturday recovered the body of a civilian flight instructor who disappeared last week when a military helicopter crashed into a lake during a night training exercise, authorities said. Phillip E. Walker's body was found about two hours after an Army helicopter raised the wreckage of the smaller aircraft from the bottom of Lake Ellsworth. ``He was doing his job. He was doing a risky job and he paid the ultimate price,'' said Maj. Chuck Pope, a Fort Sill spokesman. The 54-year-old Walker of Sheridan, Ark., was one of six crew members aboard the UHV-1 helicopter when it crashed Thursday on a night training mission over the lake just north of Fort Sill. The other five, reservists from Little Rock, Ark., escaped serious injury and were rescued from the water by lakeshore residents. ``The helicopter was in one piece with the exception of the rotor that was broken off,'' Sheila Samples, a Fort Sill spokesman, said of the wreckage. ``There was nothing in the helicopter.'' The crash's cause is unknown and under investigation. Walker, a pilot for 25 years, was a maintenance facility manager for the Army at Little Rock. He was at Fort Sill training the 374th Air Ambulance Company. The Little Rock reserve unit was activated as part of Operation Desert Shield, the deployment of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Flee Rising Rivers in Washington
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with number of evacuees to nearly 2,000, expand flooding to western part of state and update flood-stage rivers to 19, include closure of roads and an airport. Picks up 4th graf pvs: `For the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Crews scrounged for scarce sandbags and emergency shelters reopened Saturday as rain-swollen rivers spilled over and drove close to 2,000 people from their homes in the second wave of floods this season. The hardest hit areas were in western Washington. At least 19 rivers were at flood stage Saturday because of heavy rainfall in the Cascade Mountains, the National Weather Service said. Between 6 and 9 inches of rain had fallen in the mountains in 24 hours. As many as 15 highways were closed in places. Major road closures included U.S. 101 near Lake Crescent on the Olympic Peninsula and U.S. 2, a major east-west route across the state. The flooding Cedar River closed the Renton Municipal Airport. For the second time in only two weeks, scores of residents of Fir Island, about 50 miles north of Seattle, were evacuated as the rising waters of the Skagit River broke through a dike damaged in the first wave of floods. ``I think we have to assume the worst at this point because the levees are in such tough shape,'' said Mark Stewart, spokesman for the state Division of Emergency Management. ``They suffered a lot of damage in the floods two weeks and they have continued to stay saturated. ``It's a very serious situation. We're very concerned.'' The Red Cross opened emergency shelters in affected areas and the state dispatched its last 35,000 sandbags to flood fighters. The state has already gone through a stockpile of 100,000 sandbags since Veterans Day weekend. Another 150,000 were on order, but were yet to arrive. ``We are literally scouring the countryside to come up with additional sandbags,'' said Dick Milne, another spokesman for the state rescue agency. ``We've had so much rain in last two weeks - and especially in the last 24 hours - the ground is saturated and it can't go anywhere.'' Evacuations along the Skagit River could involve as many as 1,200 people, based on estimations of the number who fled two weeks ago. That first floods inflicted more than $40 million damage in Skagit, Snohomish and Whatcom counties. Gov. Booth Gardner has requested emergency federal aid for victims of that flooding. Nearly 500 people were evacuated from Fir Island during the earlier flooding, which submerged 8,000 acres of farmland. Many who had returned to begin cleaning up their homes were forced out again Saturday. Don Nieshe, 37, said he and hi family had been unable to return to their island home since the first flood and were staying with relatives on high ground. He was at the scene Saturday, surveying the damage in hip boots. The family's bicycles were loaded in a rowboat. ``There's nothing we can do. Everything's a mess inside,'' Nieshe said. The swollen Skagit River topped the island dike and created a 150-foot hole at the same point where water forced a 300-foot gap two weeks ago, undoing repair efforts. The Army Corps of Engineers planned to airdrop thousands of sandbags to fill the break. Upriver, nearly 700 people were evacuated from the rural communities of Hamilton, Cape Horn, Thunderbird and Allen. High waters between Monroe and Sultan closed an 8-mile stretch of State Highway 2. The rising Stillaguamish River lapped at the edges of Interstate 5. While rivers were rising north and east of Seattle, the state's largest city was unaffected, Milne said. There are no large rivers in the city, and a drop in elevation forces river water through Seattle quickly, not allowing it to spread beyond the river banks.

DOC.HEAD: Professors Allegations of Admissions Bias Provokes Berkeley Student Outrage
DOC.TEXT: Signs posted around the University of California-Berkeley campus last week expressed student outrage over a professor's charges of admissions discrimination against whites and Orientals. The debate over the views of anthropology Professor Vincent Sarich has grown into a controversy involving the campus chancellor and questions of free speech and academic freedom. The dispute came to a head Nov. 7 when some 75 people burst into Sarich's lecture with shouts and chants. The session was cut short. Chancellor Chang-Lin Tien has threatened expulsions of students, warning that further disruptions would not be tolerated. He also asked for an investigation. He further warned that if a complaint about Sarich's alleged ``discriminatory remarks'' were issued, a ``careful review'' of Sarich would follow. The warning alarmed faculty members who said they're concerned their courses might become limited to what is considered politically correct. ``Many of us disagree vehemently with some of the things Sarich says, but I have concern about this sort of thing getting out of hand,'' said anthropology Professor Brent Berlin. The controversy started after Sarich wrote an article in the fall for the UC alumni magazine. Sarich, a molecular anthropologist, said UC-Berkeley admissions policies ``have systematically, and increasingly, discriminated against white students and institutionalized racism on our campus.'' He said thousands of white and Asian students with perfect 4.0 grade point averages and high test scores had been denied admission to UC-Berkeley in the name of diversifying the student body. Sarich, 55, teaches what he admits are unpopular theories about human evolution, including the possibility that brain size might make a difference in intelligence, and that race may make a difference in ability. He told a reporter that he teaches biological factors that influence but don't necessarily determine differences. ``If there are any differences, they have got to be absolutely minimal as compared to ethnic and cultural differences,'' he said. Sarich said most of his students defended him after the classroom disruption, even though they may not have agreed with all of his views. ``They (the protesters) were locked onto the idea that something he was saying was racist, sexist, or homophobic ... They simply didn't know anything about what Sarich was teaching or saying,'' one of his students wrote. But English Professor David Lloyd, who had debated Sarich in the alumni journal, called Sarich ``profoundly irresponsible for what he's saying.''

DOC.HEAD: Regional Groups Seeks U.N. Chief's Help to Halt Salvadoran Violence
DOC.TEXT: Officials from El Salvador and four other nations Saturday asked the U.N. secretary-general to help halt a 5-day-old offensive that has left more than 100 people dead. At least two government soldiers died in skirmishes with leftist rebels in the eastern Usulutan province Saturday, but El Salvador's 13 other provinces appeared calm. In Honduras, the Central American Security Commission issued a statement asking U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to help end the offensive by the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation, or FMLN. They asked Perez de Cuellar to make personal efforts to persuade the rebels to call off their attacks. The group - which includes top officials from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduaras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica - said ``the bellicose actions of the FMLN constitute an obstacle'' to peace efforts in the region. The Armed Forces Press Committee in El Salvador reported fighting Saturday between rebels and soldiers in Santa Elena and El Triunfo, about 65 miles southeast of San Salvador. Two soldiers were killed in the Santa Elena fighting, according to the report. There were no casualties reported from El Triunfo. The committee said government troops in the northeastern province of Morazan discovered two graves containing the bodies of at least 12 guerrillas killed earlier in the week. Those graves - nine bodies near Lolotiquillo and three others outside Chilanga - pushed the week's death toll above 100. According to the most recent figures, 41 government soldiers, 56 rebels and eight civilians have been killed since Tuesday. An estimated 300 people have been wounded. The Santa Elena fighting was three miles from where the rebels on Friday shot down a government A-37 fighter-bomber. The government said the aircraft was downed with a Soviet-designed surface-to-air missile. The plane's pilot was killed, but the co-pilot ejected and was reported recovering from burns. Human rights groups estimate that 73,000 people have been killed in the decade-old civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BOGOTA, Colombia ^Colombia, Malaysia Balk at Supporting Force Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with Malaysia considering proposal. pick up 4th graf pvs, `Colombia, one of...'; CHANGES byline.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III failed Saturday to gain immediate support from Colombia and Malaysia for a proposed U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force to oust Iraq from Kuwait. Both countries are key non-aligned members of the U.N. Security Council. ``We had a very good meeting. They're going to study the proposals that we have talked about, the things that we have consulted with other countries about, and they will be back in touch with us,'' Baker said of his meeting in Los Angeles with Malaysian foreign minister Abu Hassan. ``Can't count votes until they're cast,'' Baker said. Hassan said he offered Baker ``no promises,'' but said he would discuss the matter with the rest of Malaysia's cabinet ministers on Wednesday. ``We are good friends of the Arab countries, both sides of Arab countries, Iraq and Saudi,'' Hassan said. Earlier Saturday, Baker met with Colombian President Cesar Gaviria and other officials during a four-hour visit to the South American nation. Afterward, Foreign Minister Luis Jaramillo said Colombia had not decided how it would vote on such a resolution. Colombia, one of 10 non-permanent members of the 15-member Security Council, has voted in favor of all 10 previous resolutions, which include a call for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and a trade embargo on Baghdad.
