But Jaramillo, speaking at a news conference with Baker, seemed to reject a military option against Iraq, saying: ``Finding peaceful solutions to conflicts is a fundamental thesis within Colombia foreign policy.'' He said, however, that Colombia stands firm with the world community in rejecting Iraqi aggression. Baker, whose visit Saturday was the last leg of a five-day tour of Security Council member states, said prospects for an immediate solution to the Persian Gulf crisis were not good. ``Perhaps the best way to achieve a peaceful solution is not to rule out the use of force. It may be the only thing Saddam Hussein understands,'' Baker told reporters. He did not indicate if the United States has enough support in the Security Council to pass such a resolution. He said prospects were not good for an immediate solution to the crisis: ``So far we see no withdrawal and in fact we see no inclination of Saddam Hussein to withdraw.'' Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 in a dispute over land, oil and money. About 350,000 troops from 26 nations are massed in Saudi Arabia against 460,000 Iraqi troops deployed in southern Iraq and Kuwait. In Beijing, Spanish Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez said Saturday the Security Council could pass the proposed resolution on using force against Iraq before the end of this week. He spoke after meeting with Chinese leaders on the gulf crisis, but made it clear that his view did not result from his discussions with them. China has refused to say how it would vote on a resolution on military force. As one of the five permanent Security Council members, China has veto power over resolutions. The other permanent members are Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. A day earlier, Britain's foreign secretary, Douglas Hurd, said the U.N. Security Council probably would meet next week to discuss the issue. It was the first indication enough support had been gathered for the measure. The Soviet Union's U.N. envoy also said Friday that Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze would attend a Security Council meeting next week to discuss Iraqi aggression - and to issue a ``strong, serious and precise warning'' to Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: Somali Rebels Claim Capture of Port, Attacks in Kenya
DOC.TEXT: Somali rebels claim they captured a strategic southern town and attacked a Kenyan border trading post. The claim could not be immediately verified from other sources. A clandestine radio broadcast by the Somali National Movement, the main rebel group, said Somali Patriotic Movement fighters were in control of the Indian Ocean port of Kisimaio. It also said the rebels staged attacks on Liboi, a Kenyan town about 110 miles northwest of the port. The Friday broadcast, monitored in Nairobi, said ``large-scale attacks'' were made on government bases at Kisimaio and rebels ``captured the town and its surrounding area.'' It said ``a similar attack'' was waged on Liboi. Kisimaio is about 220 miles south of Mogadishu, the Somali capital. The broadcast did not say when the fighting began. Attempts to reach officials by telephone in Somalia's capital of Mogadishu to verify the rebel claims were unsuccessful. A man who identified himself only as the duty officer at the Kenya police headquarters said ``we have no reports of any attack at Liboi.'' The patriotic movement is led by renegade army Col. Omar Joss and became active in southern Somalia last year. Another insurgency group, the United Somali Congress, holds much of the central part of the nation. The rebels seek the ouster of President Mohamed Siad Barre. On Wednesday, the rebels said they would not go to Cairo, Egypt, next month for peace talks with government representatives. Butros Ghalis, Egypt's foreign affairs minister, had earlier announced the talks were scheduled for Dec. 12 and that delegates would attend from Italy, Somalia's former colonial ruler. But a rebel broadcast said the guerrillas control most of Somalia ``and are not in the business of begging from anyone.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Poles Cast Absentee Ballots for Presidential Race in Homeland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 16th graf: The commission ..., to update with Poles in Michigan voting. Picks up 17th graf pvs: Stanlay Madeja...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CX3
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Poles in Chicago helped shape their homeland's future Saturday by casting absentee ballots in the first presidential election since communism's collapse in Poland. ``We are all very happy about the turnout so far. It is difficult to say how many will come,'' Andrzej Jaroszynski, a Polish consul in Chicago, said about midday. He estimated upwards of 15,000 - out of some 40,000 Chicago area Poles eligible to vote in the Polish elections - would cast ballots. Chicago has the largest bloc of Poles of any city outside Warsaw, about 800,000 to 1.2 million. Poland allows naturalized U.S. citizens to hold Polish passports and vote. Newly arrived immigrants and visitors to the United States also can vote. About 400,000 Poles in the United States were eligible to cast ballots Saturday, a day before the general election in Poland, officials said. The contest pits labor leader and Solidarity Party founder Lech Walesa against Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and four lesser known candidates. The U.S. returns could prove important if the vote is close in Poland, where more than 27 million people are eligible to vote. At the least, a high U.S. turnout would encourage the same in Poland, said Chicago Alderman Roman C. Pucinski, a Walesa backer who represents the heavily Polish 41st Ward on the city's northwest side. ``If there's a good turnout, you will have a bandwagon effect,'' Pucinski said as he stood in front of the Polish American Congress, one of three polling places in the city. A steady stream of voters moved through the modest, two-story brick building at Saturday, when an almost celebratory air pervaded the activity around voting booths. ``I just think it's great,'' Slawek Kosycarz, a 28-year-old manager of an office supply company in suburban Niles, said after casting his ballot. ``My vote was for Walesa. He's the one who brought the whole thing down.'' Danuta Stelmaszok, 37, a visitor from Dzierzoniow, Poland, and a friend, Edward Figarski, 37, a steel press operator in Chicago, took photographs of each other after voting. ``To show to family in Poland,'' said Ms. Stelmaszok, a divorcee whose parents and children remain there. A runoff will be necessary if no candidate gets 50 percent of the vote, a virtual certainty, said Elisabeth Slosarski, a member of the specially appointed Election Commission which is handling the election in the Chicago consular district. The commission is overseeing balloting at six sites in 26 states it covers - the three Chicago sites, Milwaukee, Detroit and Los Angeles. All voters must go to a designated site; no voting is permitted by mail, said consul spokesman Robert Michniewicz. In Michigan, about 1,050 Poles voted, said Jamusz Wrobel of the American Polish Congress in Hamtramck, a Detroit enclave that was the state site for casting absentee ballots. Stanlay Madeja, who was running the voting in Manhattan, said that by 1 p.m. EST, more than 1,000 Polish citizens had voted in New York City. Polling places were also open in Boston; Buffalo, N.Y.; and Passaic, N.J. Jaroszynski said all ballots would be counted by hand and results sent from each of the consular districts to Warsaw.

DOC.HEAD: Political Leader Says Cartel Chief Would Surrender Under Plan
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel is among hundreds of drug traffickers who have offered to surrender in exchange for special judicial treatment, a Colombian politician said Saturday. Cartel chief Pablo Escobar ``is absolutely interested in surrendering,'' said Diego Montana Cuellar, the former leader of the leftist Patriotic Union Party. Montana is one of four Colombian political leaders, including two former presidents, who last week delivered a cartel peace offer to the government. As many as 300 Medellin cartel members would be willing to enter a high-security compound guarded by either the army or international human rights groups, the message said. The peace offer did not specifically mention Escobar, accused of masterminding several assassinations and terrorist bombings since Colombian officials began a crackdown on drug cartels last year. Escobar was indicted by a federal grand jury in February in Tampa, Fla., on trafficking charges. He was also named in the 1988 indictment in Miami which included former Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega. Several major cartel figures have been extradited to the United States. Montana said the cartel leaders want to be judged collectively and avoid individual trials. The cartel letter also demanded the government protect surrendering traffickers from Colombian assassins, and the government should not make the traffickers confess. President Cesar Gaviria had already offered surrendering drug suspects trial in Colombia rather than extradition, and promised reduced prison sentences for traffickers who confess and become informants. Montana said Gaviria received the cartel's letter with the promise he would study it and respond to all of the proposals. ``I think the president will give the cartel a positive response within the next few days,'' Montana said. But some political analysts say the demands may be hard for the administration to accept. Many suspects are accused of trafficking aboard, but have no charges against them in Colombia. If they are not extradited, they could walk free, according to judicial experts. Government officials have also repeated they will not negotiate with the cartel, named after the city where its operations are based. Also, Montana said be believed Escobar in the next few days would release nine journalists held hostage by the cartel. ``Escobar ordered the kidnappings of the journalists to use them as a shield from authorities,'' Montana said. ``Now that he is planning to turn himself in, he no longer needs the hostages.''

DOC.HEAD: Speeding Bus Collides With Train; At Least 16 Dead
DOC.TEXT: A bus speeding to reach a railway crossing slammed into a train Saturday, killing at least 16 people, local newspapers reported. At least 16 bus passengers were injured, and no one on the train was hurt. Police said some passengers were saved by a group of doctors traveling on the train in Chaiyapum province, about 170 miles northeast of Bangkok, the Nation newspaper reported Sunday. The reports say the bus driver stepped on the accelerator to try to reach the crossing first, but the bus crashed into a passenger carriage.

President Bush, relaxing at Camp David after returning from the Middle East and Europe, says he's confident the United Nations will approve using force to drive Iraq from Kuwait and perhaps a deadline for taking action. ``The world is getting tired of this,'' Bush said Friday of Iraq's nearly four-month-old occupation of Kuwait. Bush arrived home early today from the Middle East after stopping in Geneva for three hours of talks with Syrian President Hafez Assad. The White House said the two leaders agreed that Iraq ``should receive no reward for its aggression'' and that there should be no `partial solutions'' to the Persian Gulf crisis. Assad sidestepped a question of whether Syrian forces would fight alongside Americans in an offensive operation. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush and Assad held ``an extended conversation on the question of terrorism.'' Syria, on the State Department's list of nations that sponsor terrorism, is suspected of having links to acts including the bombings of Pan Am Flight 103 in 1988 and the U.S. Marine barracks in Beirut in 1983. ---= LONDON (AP) - Even as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's supporters claim she was undermined by her own party, a poll indicates any of the three main candidates for her job will bring an election victory for the troubled Conservatives. The Harris poll of 1,107 voters around the country is the latest survey to predict a sharp upturn in Conservative Party fortunes under a new prime minister. Under Mrs. Thatcher the Conservatives trailed Labor, the main opposition party in the House of Commons, for the past 16 months in opinion polls. The poll was conducted on Thursday after Mrs. Thatcher announced she would resign. ---=

Swarms of shoppers are descending on the nation's malls and stores this holiday weekend, but the jingle of the Christmas cashbox may not be loud enough to spread cheer among shopkeepers. ``I am going to spend less this year because the economy is bad and money is tight,'' shopper Joyce Sylvia of Providence, R.I., said Friday. A worsening national recession and the Persian Gulf crisis may lead to the worst holiday sales in years. Many people say their Christmas lists are shorter and they're buying cheaper presents. ``People who I might buy a sweater for in good years this year may get gloves or a scarf,'' said Henrietta Beasley of Monroe, Ga. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Supporters of the proposed Two Forks Dam in Colorado say they may go to court to challenge a decision by federal environmental officials to kill the project. If the veto of the dam by the Environmental Protection Agency is sustained, it could set a precedent for similar projects, they said. William H. Van Schooneveld, chairman of the Metropolitan Water Providers that sponsored the Colorado dam, said, ``This decision affects not just Denver, but it may be the end of all big water projects. If EPA can veto this, there really isn't any project that anybody can develop that can pass the EPA.'' ``There are a lot of grounds for (a federal court) appeal,'' he said. EPA announced the veto of the dam Friday night, confirming earlier unofficial reports. The dam would have been the largest non-federal water project in the West. It had been supported by Reagan administration officials.

DOC.HEAD: From Ice Cream To Smoked Quail, Mail-Order Food Market Revs Up For Holidays
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf `Based in...' with one graf to conform to accompanying AP graphic by DELETING total sales references and ADDING Harry and David's corporate parent's name. This story moved in advance for Sunday release on general news wires as b0629, and also on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: With AP Graphic
DOC.TEXT: 'Tis the season for mail-order giving, and more of the gifts crisscrossing the nation make for a transportable feast. Fruit in the mail is nothing new, but how about six pints of assorted gelato packed in dry ice? It's yours, if someone doesn't mind paying $10 a pint to get it to you. And forget the mundane fruitcake. Select instead a bouquet of porcini mushrooms, a pair of smoked quail or a basket of prickly pears. The 3,600 companies that tempt the palate with mail-order edibles are competing for the $1.2 billion that Americans are expected to spend on food orders this year, according to a recent study by the New York market research firm FIND-SVP. Growing at an annual rate of about 10 percent, mail-order foods are likely to account for more than $3 billion in sales by the year 2000, FIND-SVP said. Business whips into a frenzy during the final quarter, with some mail-order companies doing virtually all their shipping between September and January. Entire 747 jets have been stuffed with nothing but thousands of pounds of holiday pears from Harry and David. Harry and David, a Yamanouchi Pharmaceutical division based in Medford, Ore., is among the nation's largest mail-order food companies. According to FIND-SVP, the top 10 food-by-mail companies control 45 percent of the market; about 3,000 companies are characterized as ``mom-and-pop'' operations, each with sales of less than $50,000 a year. Though the vast majority of food moves by ground transportation, most of the industry's growth is in overnight and two-day delivery services, which can guarantee a delicate or perishable item arrives intact. Clambake Celebrations of Cape Cod, Mass., for example, can promise a customer in Albuquerque, N.M., that she will have lobster, mussels and a few ears of corn - all packed in authentic seaweed - steaming on the stove less than 48 hours after phoning in the order. The cost: $119.95 for two. San Francisco's Gelato Classico Italian Ice Cream is just begining to offer its products by mail. Six pints - which comprise a minimum order at $59.95 - are packaged in dry ice in a foam container much like a picnic cooler. Consultant Jay Walker, who heads Ridgefield, Conn.-based Catalog Media Corp., said that though food-by-mail has been big business for a long time, ``overnight delivery ... allowed a freshness perception for millions of people who didn't believe they could get (food) fresh in the mail. And it made sure food can be given as a gift reliably.'' If you ask Federal Express, spokesman Brandon Davis will tell you his company has been a major boost to the food industry. ``Our business ... allows them to extend their business season right up to Dec. 21,'' he said. ``If you do 80 percent of your business in one or two months of the year and can extend that selling season by just two weeks, it's a tremendous boost.'' Companies with very narrow product lines can stay in business because they cater to a national - rather than local - clientele. Franklin Foods of North Franklin, Conn., for example, sells only exotic mushrooms like Polish cepes, shiitakes and porcinis. Smithfield, Va.-based Fin 'N Feather will put a smoked pheasant buffet on your table. Mr. Spear Inc. of Stockton, Calif., has cultivated a list of 25,000 fans of its colossal asparagus, its sole product. ``It's an alternative to flowers,'' said president Chip Arnett. His super-premium asparagus, which has been served at the White House, simply is ``not in sufficient enough quantities to make it available from a retail standpoint,'' he said. Consultant Walker believes the food-by-mail business is ``countercyclical'' to the economy - that is, as the recession deepens, business is likely to increase. Consumers who feel pinched for cash typically ``trade down'' when it comes to buying gifts, and food is a popular alternative because it has ``no comparative market price,'' Walker said. ``You don't know if a dozen apples from an orchard in Oregon is a $20 gift or a $40 gift,'' he said. Perusing catalogs in the coziness of one's own home and ordering with the mere push of telephone buttons has become a recreational pastime of sorts for many Americans. ``People are sitting home and they're bored and so they pick up the phone and buy on a credit card,'' said Debbie Cohen, a national saleswoman for Melissa's World Variety Produce Inc., a Los Angeles company that specializes in shipping in exotic produce like purple potatoes, elephant garlic and prickly pears. Though consumers who buy foods through the mail make up less than 2 percent of the population, they are an affluent lot willing to pay more for convenience and a guarantee of quality. A pint of Gelato Classico costs just $3.95 in one of the company's 32 shops, but the minimum 6-pit mail order commands a $36 shipping charge. Too extravagant to buy for yourself, perhaps, but an exquisite gift to give. The mail-order business does have its limitations. Identifying customers can be costly, and it is difficult to adapt quickly to changes in consumer taste. A company that must put together its Christmas catalog by August can't suddenly decide to replace its pecan pie if cranberries become the rage. In addition, the threat of higher postal rates always looms large. Third-class postage, the rate for most catalogs, has increased more than 350 percent since 1970, and the U.S. Postal Service is planning another rate hike for February. Mail-order companies are being pressed to collect sales taxes on a higher proportion of their sales, forcing them to compete harder against local retailers. Finally, since the food business is seasonal, some companies actually are forced to shut down during spring and summer. Others try to round out their offerings with other products. Harry and David, for example, has a sister company called Jackson and Perkins, a gardening and flower concern, which helps smooth out sales throughout the year. To further entice customers, many companies have a ``thing-of-the-month'' plan. For $219.95, Harry and David will send a box of fruit once a month; for $720, Gelato will send six pints of its super-premium ice cream 12 times a year, and you get to choose among flavors like fresh ginger, double espresso and Coppa Mista, with swirls of chocolate, vanilla, pistachio and almond ice creams. Among other ``special'' services companies provide, Baskets of Elegance, a California fashioner of gourmet food baskets, sends customers a color photograph of their orders before they're shipped.
